Warsaw Pact doctrines tend to focus on reducing dissent and promoting national unity

Integrating all NATO members’ militaries into one unified command will standardize allied military terminology, procedures, and technology. Roughly 1300 Standardization Agreements codify many of the common practices that NATO uses. For instance, the 7.62x51 NATO rifle cartridge is introduced as the standard firearm cartridge, aircraft marshalling signals are standardized, and the NATO phonetic alphabet is adopted. Standardization makes international military cooperation more efficient and increases NATO readiness.

Political pluralism is the principle of permitting peaceful coexistence between disparate interests, convictions, and lifestyles under a democratic regime. The philosophy acknowledges the diversity of interests and emphasizes the need for members of a society to accommodate one another’s interests by engaging in good-faith negotiation. Political pluralism can lead to a society that seems to be disorderly and chaotic, but it may also lead to long-term societal stability and greater personal creativity and freedom.

Although obligated to respond to an attack by an aggressor against the alliance, including against any member's territory, naval vessels, ground forces, or aircraft, the doctrine of joint non-political control holds that NATO member states will remain free to choose the exact method by which they respond. Therefore, this doctrine maintains alliance legitimacy and combats inter-alliance rivalry by assuring states that they will not be compelled into taking action against their direct national interests.

Duck and Cover is a drill taught to school children to protect them against an unexpected nuclear attack. Upon seeing a flash, children are taught to ‘duck’ under their desks or tables and ‘cover’ their exposed skin and heads with any loose clothing. These precautions ensure that children immediately seek cover after seeing a flash of light instead of rushing outside or to windows to investigate, where they are more vulnerable to the nuclear blast wave.

Rational choice theory is a framework for understanding and modeling economic behavior.  It defines rationality as 'wanting more rather than less of a good' and is widely used as an assumption of the behavior of individuals in microeconomic models in market-based economic theories. Rational choice theory attempts to predict how economic actors decide to make purchases given certain preferences.

The efficient market hypothesis holds that financial markets are ‘informationally efficient’ and instantaneously take into account both publicly traded information and ‘insider’ information. Consequently, the theory holds that it is impossible to achieve consistent returns in excess of the average given information available at the time an investment is made. The efficient market hypothesis informs the way that investments are made and is able to fundamentally alter the behavior of financial markets.

Planned obsolescence in industrial design is a policy of designing a product with a limited useful life in order to insure that it will become obsolete after a certain time period has passed. Some methods of achieving planned obsolescence are by using cheap materials in construction or ensuring that a product’s desirability is beholden to variable trends fashion. Planned obsolescence is useful for stimulating demand by encouraging purchasers to continue buying if they want a functioning product.

‘Are these things really better than the things I already have? Or am I just trained to be dissatisfied with what I have now?’ –Chuck Palahniuk, Lullaby. Consumerism is a social and economic regime that encourages the purchase of goods and services in ever-increasing amounts. The economic activity created by this cycle of consuming, discarding, and consuming again is taxed by a government in order to generate potentially huge revenues and fund state projects, the military, espionage, etc.

Keynesian economics is the view that short-term economic activity is strongly influenced by total spending in the economy, especially in times of economic recession or crisis. It teaches that an economy’s total spending does not necessarily equal its productive capacity, but rather behaves erratically because of the influence of a host of factors. Therefore, Keynesian economics advocates a primarily private sector economy with a strong regulatory presence by the government.

The Great Society is a set of domestic programs implemented with the goal of eliminating poverty and racial injustice through social programs such as state-subsidized healthcare, social security funds, urban renewal, fair housing initiatives, etc. Great society programs are vulnerable to criticism for their expense as well as for their stated goal of reforming society as a whole, which can draw fire from a nation’s conservative elements.

Supply-side economics teaches that the lowering of barriers to producers of goods and services is the best way to generate economic growth. By lowering taxes and reducing regulation producers will be able to produce a greater supply of goods and services, thus lowering the price of those goods and services for consumers. However, supply-side economics is vulnerable to criticism that it mainly benefits high income earners and does not generate enough revenues to justify its lower tax rates.

Containment is a strategy for containing the spread of communism throughout the world rather than accommodating it or attempting to reverse it. It therefore represents a middle ground position between these two poles. Specific strategies for containment include fighting defensive wars to protect pro-democratic countries from communist invaders, the use of international sanctions against communist countries, and the development of anti-communist institutions worldwide.

Totalitarian regimes rely on strict censorship of national media to maintain control of the country, reporting news in a way that glorifies the regime or even omitting negative news altogether. Generally, the population knows that its news is under the state’s control, so providing an alternative news source not beholden to the government can be a powerful force for encouraging dissent. Radio Liberty attempts to provide such a news source by broadcasting news by radio into the territory of totalitarian states.

Loyalty programs are responses to the perceived threat of communists within the governments of democratic nations. They attempt to uncover communists in the government through wide-ranging investigation and dismiss those whose communist ties are too strong to tolerate. Loyalty programs also compile a list of subversive organizations to better flag personnel who potentially pose security risks. If not tightly controlled, loyalty programs can spiral out of control and descend into communist witch hunts.

Peace through partnership with the allies of democracy is a foreign policy doctrine that advocates allowing each ally nation to be in charge of its own general security, with NATO acting as a ‘nuclear umbrella’ upon request. Under this doctrine, NATO will not immediately intervene when communism spreads into other nations, as it would under containment, but rather seeks to empower independent nations to provide for their own security with NATO assistance, if requested.

Rollback is the doctrine of compelling regime change in a state by forcing out communist regimes from nations where they have seized power. Rollback is typically executed by engaging in open warfare against a ruling communist regime and forcing its capitulation by annihilating its military. However, this strategy often risks sparking war with the Soviet Union or other communist sponsor who might be supporting the communist regime of the target nation.

Supercarrier doctrine differs from normal carrier strike group doctrine in scale and capability. Supercarriers are aircraft carriers displacing more than 70,000 tons and operating 80-90 aircraft, giving their air wings unprecedented offensive capability. Organizing a carrier strike group around a supercarrier generally requires tweaking the combat roles of support ships, most prominently the increased role of logistical support and anti-submarine warfare.

NATO nuclear cruisers are designed to escort nuclear supercarriers. They provide air defense and anti-submarine support but also wield a strong missile capability, both anti-ship and ground attack. The combat mission of nuclear missile cruisers primarily includes carrier escort, air control, and other defense operations. Historically, all western nuclear cruisers were decommissioned and replaced with conventionally propelled models because of the expense of maintaining them.

The Aegis Combat System is an advanced command and control and weapon control system that integrates data from radar, sonar, and satellite detection systems in order to track and guide weapons to destroy enemy targets. It can operate simultaneously in tracking and defeating incoming enemy attacks and directing strikes against targets. The Aegis System can even track and destroy short- and medium-range ballistic missiles. It is primarily used in naval combat and is installed on cruiser-size vessels.

Society does not consist of individuals, but expresses the sum of interrelations, the relations within which these individuals stand.' –Karl Marx. Historical materialism is the idea that society is fundamentally based on economic relationships, e.g. employee-employer, worker-industrialist, etc. Marx theorized that revolutions occur when these social relationships can no longer efficiently govern production. Historical materialism is a means of understanding history based on these relationships.

Forming the theoretical foundation of Marxism, dialectical materialism is a theory for systematizing and understanding reality. It emphasizes the tension between 'opposites' at every level of existence as a way to understand revolution and social change. 'For [dialectical philosophy] nothing is final, absolute, sacred...Nothing can endure before it except the uninterrupted process of becoming and passing away, of endless ascendancy from the lower to the higher.' –Fredrick Engels.

Marxism-Leninism is an ideology that seeks to create an international communist society by way of workers' revolution. Once a nation’s workers are 'awakened' to the true nature of society as seen by Marxism, they will autonomously form a revolutionary vanguard that will carry the proletariat’s dictate to all levels of society, thus establishing communism. Marxism-Leninism focuses on the mobilization of a nation’s working class against wealthy segments of society in order to seize power.

Permanent revolution is a Marxist theory adapted by Leon Trotsky to be a prescription for how to attain communism directly from feudal aristocracy without first passing through advanced capitalism. Under Marxist theory, a society must progress from feudalism to capitalism and finally, through a revolutionary socialist awakening, to communism. Permanent revolution advocates the proletariat’s mobilization of the still-feudal peasantry to jump straight into communism.

'Freedom of discussion, unity of action - this is what we must strive to achieve.' –Lenin. Democratic centralism is the idea that all Supreme Soviet policies are open for debate initially, but once a decision has been made there is no room for dissent. This ideal evolved over time: by the time of Stalin’s reign, the Supreme Soviet – nominally invested with sweeping legislative power – acted as a rubber stamp for whichever policies the communist party dictated.

Stalinism takes its name from Joseph Stalin who implemented a number of measures in the USSR aimed at modernizing the country and securing it against foreign aggression, both real and imagined. These included rapid industrialization, agricultural collectivization, and the extreme centralization of Soviet decision making. In the process, Stalinism resulted in the notorious Red Army purges, mass Ukrainian famine, and the ascendency of the secret police – the NKVD.

By the middle of the 1920s, communism had failed to take hold in all countries except for the former Russian Empire. Reacting to this failure to live up to the Marxist-Leninist prophecy of world revolution, Joseph Stalin proclaimed the new state policy of pursuing 'socialism in one country' by turning inward to strengthen communism in the Soviet Union and wait for more favorable conditions to carry out the revolution abroad.

A cult of personality is similar to hero worship, except that mass media (television, newspaper, books, radio, etc) create a cult of personality. It is characterized by a god-like public image and constant, repetitious praise and aggrandizement of the locus of the cult. This creates an aura of invincible, omnipresent, and omnipotent authority around the person at the center of the cult. Some examples of the personality cult include those of Joseph Stalin, Mao Zedong, and Adolf Hitler.

'Political power grows out of the barrel of a gun.' –Mao Zedong. Maoist thought holds that capitalist society exploits the rural-industrial divide to oppress the multitude of the people. It therefore conceives of the peasantry, rather than the industrial proletariat, as the primary force to effect communist revolution in a capitalist society. Central to Maoist ideology is the notion of the People’s War: a low-level, guerrilla-style campaign of violence against established institutions.

New Democracy is a set of policies implemented by Mao Zedong which were intended to be a prescription for how to attain communism directly from feudal aristocracy. Under Marxist theory, a society had to progress from feudalism to capitalism and finally to communism by way of revolutionary socialist awakening. New Democracy advocates the mobilization of society led by a communist party of workers in order to jump straight into communism by destroying the old capitalist order.

The Cultural Revolution was a response to the perceived infiltration of bourgeois 'revisionists' into Chinese communist society who aimed to undo communism and restore the old order. Mao Zedong advocated the rejection of anything western or 'capitalist' by violent class struggle. Empowered by Chairman Mao’s decrees, Chinese communists carried out the Cultural Revolution across all levels of Chinese society, with much bloodshed.

Thought reform is the attempt to impose communist modes of thought on a nation’s citizenry, especially its intellectual class. Marxist doctrine teaches that every person is capable of socialist awakening and class consciousness: thought reform is the government’s enforcement of that awakening in every citizen. The Communist party implemented thought reform with the massive use of propaganda, mass conversion movements, ordering of self-criticism, and sessions of public humiliation.

‘Those who own the youth, own the future.’ -Slogan of the German Young Pioneers. Young Pioneer movements are communist-funded organizations that induct a nation’s young people. Young Pioneers do good works and in fact are modeled on the U.S. Boy Scouts, but where the Scout movement is independent of political or government control, Young Pioneer movements exist with the communist party’s blessing. Membership is not mandatory, but Young Pioneers can grow to make excellent Party members.

The political commissar bolsters the military’s political consciousness with revolutionary political education and organization. Commissars also ensured that military units maintained their revolutionary zeal (i.e. morale). Because they held the same rank as the commanding officer of the unit to which they were assigned, political commissars could, if necessary, countermand orders and take direct control of units to ensure that every comrade did his duty.

Supercavitation is a physical phenomenon that occurs when a high speed object forms a bubble from the tip of its nose that extends along its length, thus keeping the body of the object from touching the water and drastically reducing drag. This allows the object to achieve very high speeds and perform like an underwater rocket – excellent for attacking enemy submarines.

Supersonic missiles developed by the Soviet Union were deployed extensively on guided missile destroyers and cruisers, and even on carriers. They generally used liquid-fueled rocket motors or ramjet engines to achieve speeds of Mach 2-4. Because of their high speed, large warhead (conventional or nuclear), and long range (enabled by satellite or helicopter guidance), they are commonly called ‘carrier killers.’

Supersonic missiles developed by the Soviet Union were deployed extensively smaller boats and corvettes. They generally used liquid-fueled rocket motors or ramjet engines to achieve speeds of Mach 2-4. Because of their high speed and large warhead (conventional or nuclear), they are extremely effective at destroying targets inside their ranges. Furthermore, short range missiles are small enough to fit on a wide variety of vessels, thus allowing a navy to field numerous small craft armed with the deadly weapons.

The nuclear battlecruiser is an enormous, heavily-armed version of a modern cruiser – nearly the size of a WWI battleship. It carries a huge number of anti-ship missiles, as well as ASW missiles and surface-to-air missiles for air defense. Nuclear battlecruiser doctrine calls for the organization of a surface action group around the battlecruiser to enable it to wield its anti-ship missiles to greatest effect. Support ships provide anti-air support, anti-submarine capability, and supplemental anti-ship missile fire.

Theocracy is a form of government in which a deity is officially recognized as the civil ruler and official policy is governed by officials who are regarded as divinely guided, or is a form of government pursuant to the doctrine of a particular religion or religious group. A theocracy may have an administrative hierarchy of the government identical with the administrative hierarchy of the religion, or it may have two 'arms' with the state administrative hierarchy subordinate to the religious hierarchy.

Some societies have religious police who enforce the application of religious law. Their authority may include the power to arrest unrelated men and women caught socializing, anyone engaged in homosexual behavior or prostitution, and to enforce dress #CODEs and store closures during prayer time, among other activities. The role of the religious police in society is to guard the ‘nation’s morality’ by preventing the occurrence of activities that the religious state regards as degenerate and harmful to society.

A holy war is a war caused or justified by religious differences. Religion is often one of the only tools within a state’s repertoire that can effectively mobilize large parts of its population, and it therefore makes sense to use religion to rally popular support for a war. Some goals of religious war include the liberation of subjugated peoples of the same faith in other countries, to spread religion by violence, or to suppress another religious group because of its beliefs or practices.

Fascism as an official political ideology is thoroughly discredited after the Allies’ victory over the Axis powers in WWII and the collapse of multiple fascist regimes in Europe. However, the post-WWII political landscape included many governments ideologically related to fascism. These governments tend to emphasize nationalism and even racial purity as the best way to maintain a functioning society.

National identity acts as a unifying force for groups of people around the world, transcending state borders and religions. When a nation, defined as a group of people who share a common national identity, is coupled with a state of its own, it is referred to as a nation-state. Nation-states benefit from the unity bestowed by a common nationality but almost always contain other minority nations within their borders, which can lead to persecution if the state determines that the national minority poses a threat to its internal stability.

A supreme leader is a figure who occupies the highest leadership position of a state and exercises all-powerful authority over it. Authority is cemented with a cult of personality centered on the supreme leader that delegitimizes all dissent to his rule. A state headed by a supreme leader is typically very stable under his iron grip, but suffers from the regime’s extreme intolerance of any political dissent.

Thought reform, also known as mind control or brainwashing, encompasses any tactic that seeks to alter an individual’s control over his or her own decision making, behavior, thoughts, or emotions. These tactics can be applied to prisoners of war (POWs) in order to elicit confessions or statements against their home countries, or to a nation’s population itself as part of a program to crush internal dissent. Successful thought reform may even induce former POWs to defect once returned to their home unit.

Youth movements are organizations where young people collectively participate in activities that are meant to bolster civic consciousness and group cooperation. Totalitarian regimes co-opt these groups for the dual purpose of indoctrinating the nation’s youth and ensuring that the youth spend their free time in ways that are productive to the regime. Youth movements mostly act a passive means of controlling a nation’s youth, but they can also be mobilized to carry out the regime’s goals if the need arises.

Informal social control refers to the reactions of groups and individuals to bring about conformity rather than social control through governmental authorities. Examples include peer pressure, citizen patrols, or bystander intervention in a crime. More traditional societies generally exert more informal social control over their members than urban, industrial societies where social mobility and anonymity tend to break down informal constraints on behavior.

A ‘Foreign Legion’ (most famously the French Foreign Legion) is a unit of soldiers drawn from civilian volunteers, and is characterized by its willingness to accept individuals regardless of their background and assign them a new identity. Consequently, such a unit attracts people who are fleeing their civilian lives – criminals, social outcasts, and rejects from other militaries. Foreign Legion units frequently deploy to combat and are able to absorb greater losses than regular army units without public outcry.

Colonial troops are forces raised from among the population of a nation’s colonial possessions. Typically, they are led by the imperial nation’s own officers but noncommissioned officers and enlisted men are overwhelmingly drawn from the local population. Colonial troops are familiar with their home country’s terrain and demographics, and therefore are particularly well-suited to low-intensity conflict. However, they can perform very well in conventional warfare, as well.

A technical is a type of improvised fighting vehicle that has been modified with the addition of weaponry to provide an offensive capability. Typically, technicals are armed with one or more machine guns for light anti-aircraft or fire support applications. However, mounting recoilless rifles to the vehicles can provide a light anti-armor capability. Technicals rely heavily on speed and concealment to compensate for their complete lack of armor.

A paramilitary is a force whose function and organization is similar to a professional military, but which is not considered part of a state’s formal armed forces. These types of units may be organized to fulfill police roles, guerrilla combat, insurgency, border guards, counterrevolution, or anti-terrorist roles. Although paramilitary forces can be deployed in combat, they are unable to resist regular adversaries without incurring heavy losses.

Centralized command and control is the concentration of authority at the top of a military hierarchy and allowing only limited initiative to lower level commanders. Centralized authority works well when lower level commanders cannot effectively use information they have at hand to make sound battlefield decisions. By concentrating authority where the most information is available and subordinating lower echelons to that command, militaries become more effective warfighters.

Mass firepower is the doctrine of applying overwhelming force to an enemy position with as many weapons as possible in order to break the enemy’s will to fight or to maneuver against the enemy while he is suppressed. Careful force management is often necessary to achieve sufficient firepower to achieve this effect. On the defensive, mass firepower doctrine calls for the ambushed or outnumbered unit to immediately respond with as much fire as possible in order to facilitate a tactical withdrawal.

Attrition warfare is the military strategy of grinding down an enemy through constant losses of manpower and materiel. The goal of attrition warfare is to force the enemy to yield when these losses reach a critical point where they become unsustainable. Attrition warfare is usually employed by belligerents who lack better options such as maneuver warfare, but the strategy can be useful for defenders who seek to wear down an opponent to the political breaking point.

Shock tactics attempt to induce the enemy to break his position by placing him under extreme psychological stress with sudden and committed maneuvers against his position. Cavalry charges traditionally served this purpose and modern shock attacks are usually performed by armored forces such as tanks and infantry fighting vehicles. This doctrine seeks to implement any tactic that is aimed at breaking the enemy’s morale with a single bold maneuver, with armored forces or otherwise.

‘All war is deception.’ –Sun Tzu. Military deception is the art and science of misleading one’s enemy during warfare in order to achieve surprise or make the enemy misallocate his resources. In modern war, deception can range from concealing one’s forces in ambush to strategic operations aimed at inflating the numbers and disposition of troops or weapons in ones possession. Successful deception results in taking the enemy by surprise and forcing him to fight where you have the advantage.

Infiltration tactics rely on small infantry teams bypassing strong points to attack the rear, causing disarray and leaving the front vulnerable. The infiltration teams are lightly equipped in order to move swiftly and remain unnoticed until the attack beings. Infiltration tactics are only effective when a heavier attack can follow up on the chaos sewn behind enemy lines, and therefore represent only a useful tool in a unit’s repertoire. Often, the tactical situation will render infiltration tactics infeasible or too costly to employ.

Special operations forces are highly-trained military units that perform unconventional, high-risk missions. Special Forces typically perform missions like long-distance reconnaissance in enemy territory, training of indigenous military forces, raiding and interdiction behind enemy lines, and counterterrorism and hostage rescue. Special Forces operations require a particular type of solider: one who is intelligent, resourceful, tenacious, and comfortable operating without much external support.

Maneuver warfare advocates the concentration of force against weak points in an enemy formation by rapidly maneuvering one’s forces to attack those points. The doctrine focuses on destroying the enemy’s ability to make decisions with shock and disruption, leaving him powerless to mobilize effective resistance. Modern maneuver warfare focuses heavily on reconnaissance and the rapid – mechanized, if possible – movement of troops to attack the ascertained weak points in the enemy’s formation.

Mechanized warfare refers to the systematic use of vehicles in combat for tactical and strategic mobility as well as to overcome the enemy’s defenses. Mechanized warfare uses trucks, motorcycles, and armored vehicles to rapidly transport forces around the battlefield. It also emphasizes the use of armored fighting vehicles like tanks and self-propelled guns to punch through enemy formations and exploit the breach. Mechanized warfare relegates traditional foot mobile infantry to a secondary, supporting role.

A hedgehog defense is a response to armored attack where the defenders deploy in depth in heavily fortified positions suitable for all-around defense. The attackers are allowed to pass between the ‘hedgehogs’ but each position is able to fight on while surrounded, forcing the attackers to defeat each one in turn and slowing their movement through formation. Hedgehogs are very reliant on air support for resupply and must be skillfully deployed for mutual support in order to resist determined assault.

Elastic defense, also known as defense in depth, seeks to delay an enemy’s advance through an area rather than attempting to stop him with a single strong line. The defender’s delaying tactics are aimed at absorbing the attacker’s momentum: the defender attempts to resist the attack over a large area and force him to pacify successive defensive positions. Once the attack becomes overextended, counterattacks are directed at weak points in the enemy’s formation in order to cause attrition or retake ground.

‘The mind of the enemy and the will of his leaders is a target of far more importance than the bodies of his troops.’ –Mao Zedong. Psychological warfare is the attempted influencing of a target audience’s value systems, beliefs, emotions, reasoning, or behavior for one’s own benefit. Methods include the broadcast of propaganda via radio stations, loudspeakers, and false flag events, but also attempting to build 'soft power' by undertaking civil projects such as medical clinics and schools for local populations.

‘The doctrine that guides infantry forces is based on the four elements of combat power: maneuver, firepower, protection, and leadership.’ –US Army FM-7-8. Fire and maneuver is the tactic of using a heavy volume of fire to suppress an enemy unit’s ability to fight while simultaneously moving to attack his position. The maneuver element moves under cover of the fire element’s suppressing fire to a position where they can kill the enemy, usually on a flank at close range, using rifle fire and grenades.

Indirect fire is the technique of aiming and firing of a high angle of incidence weapon, like an artillery gun or mortar, without a direct line of sight between the gun and its target. Aiming is achieved by manipulation of azimuth and elevation based on communications with a guiding method ranging from a simple forward observer, to advanced radar guidence. Indirect fire is hugely advantageous because it allows great flexibility in artillery placement but the procedure is very sophisticated and requires lots of training to do well.

Human wave attack is an offensive infantry tactic where an attacker assaults an enemy position with an unprotected mass of closely-packed infantry, with the goal of capturing the position with hand to hand combat. Because the human wave tactic relies on melee combat, the training and organization of the attacking force is largely irrelevant. Therefore, the human wave attack is best suited to a force of poorly-trained and -equipped infantry whose main advantage is motivating and controlling its men.

Swarming tactics refer to the use of autonomous or semi-autonomous units to attack an enemy from several different directions at once, regrouping after the attacks are complete. Swarming tactics are nothing new – the Mongol horse archers used them to great effect – but their codification into a unitary doctrine applicable to modern warfare allows low level units to operate within a traditional top-down command structure with greater flexibility and effectiveness.

Asymmetric warfare refers to armed conflict between opponents of unequal military capabilities or military power. For instance, asymmetric warfare occurs when a mechanized military of tanks and aircraft engages an indigenous insurgency that wields little more than small arms. Asymmetry of power forces the less powerful belligerent to engage in unconventional warfare because attempting to fight a conventional war would result in annihilation.

Low Intensity Operations refers to the use of military force in a limited or restrained manner in order to defeat an insurgency of non-state actors in a country. Because this does not rise to the level of all-out war and the objective of low intensity operations is to pacify an insurgency, the superior firepower use by modern militaries is not nearly as useful as in conventional warfare. Rather, low intensity operations represent a long-term commitment to the systematic restoration of normalcy to civilian life.

The inkblot strategy is a way for subduing a large hostile region with a smaller military force. The occupying force begins by establishing numerous small safe areas dispersed across the region, then pushing out in stages from each area and extending its control over the region until the ‘ink blots’ converge into a zone of total control. Any remaining pockets of resistance are easier to overcome when surrounded and cut off.

A ‘flypaper’ strategy is the idea that it is best to draw the enemy into a single area where it is easier to kill them and that is also far away from one’s own vulnerabilities, such as civilian population centers where collateral damage from battle would be high. The strategy’s effectiveness depends on how much of the enemy will be drawn to the ‘flytrap’ and how easy it will be to kill them once they are trapped.

Recondo is short for RECONnaissance and commanDO and refers to specialized asymmetric warfare infantry training. These schools intensively train soldiers to lead small teams of heavily armed infantry deep into enemy territory on long-range reconnaissance missions. These missions are extremely hazardous because they operate almost without any support, but can inflict extremely high kill to death ratios on an enemy and produce valuable intelligence.

‘The essential task of the guerrilla fighter is to keep himself from being destroyed.’ –Che Guevara. Guerrilla warfare focuses on the use of small, highly mobile units to harass unwieldy conventional forces. By never allowing itself to be decisively defeated in a pitched battle, a guerrilla unit is able to continuously strike opportunistically against its opponent, eventually forcing its withdrawal. Guerrilla forces heavily rely on terrain favorable to small units and the support of local populations to avoid defeat.

A guerrilla force must take any opportunity it can to engage its enemy in a fight where it has the advantage. One way of doing this is to prepare a position ahead of time and lure the enemy into it with ‘bait’ tactics. Exactly what constitutes effective bait tactics largely depends on accurately predicting how the enemy will respond to contact. For instance, an opponent can be tricked into assuming that a position is weak and pressing the attack if the position’s forward fortifications are scattered and lightly-contested.

Nations employ propaganda in warfare in order to sway local support to their cause. Importantly, the propaganda’s message need not be true to be effective: the side who employs propaganda most effectively will generally succeed in gaining public support. Propaganda is disseminated via radio, pamphlets, posters, and newspapers.

Defensive positions arranged in two lines with interlocking fields of fire allow a guerrilla or light infantry force to maximize its firepower against an attacker. The two belts of fortifications are spaced 50 to 100 meters apart, depending on the terrain, and shaped like an L, U, or V to allow interlocking fire. Individual positions as well as bunkers and communication trenches are constructed, as well. These defensive precautions are essential to a guerrilla unit’s survival and they are built every time it changes its position.

‘One Slow, Four Quick’ is a guerrilla method for attacking enemy positions. The ‘slow’ phase refers to the covert buildup of supplies and troops in the vicinity of the target position. The four ‘quick’ phases are quick advance, where forces quickly move to their assigned positions, quick attack, where the forces attack at the weakest point of the enemy position, quick clearance, where the battlefield is cleared of weapons and equipment, and quick withdrawal to a pre-arranged rendezvous point.

Missile-centered surface groups require specific tactics to ensure that the group’s missile strength is maximized and its vulnerabilities mitigated. Missile warfare requires careful concealment of the main strike force until the enemy’s location is ascertained, then rapid maneuvering to engage while maintaining as much stealth as possible. Depending on the range of the group’s missile weapons, engagement can occur very early and decisively, but combat with carrier battle groups requires more finesse.

The strike group is a flexible naval force organized around a capital or command ship that can operate in confined waters or in the open ocean during the day or at night and in all weather conditions. Strike group doctrine dictates the respective roles of each individual ship in the strike group, organizing forces by combat mission rather than by platform. The doctrine emphasizes the ability to rapidly focus firepower on a target and retain flexibility to respond to changing tactical situations.

Close escort doctrine focuses on formations and combat strategies for swift and highly maneuverable warships designed for escorting task forces or convoys of merchant marine ships. Escort ships provide a valuable screen for their task force or convoy, detecting enemy forces before the enemy detects the main force. Escorts are also able to engage enemy forces that they encounter but their small size limits their armament, forcing them to rely on the main task force’s firepower to destroy powerful enemy forces.

Providing ground support fire has always been a primary mission of naval strike groups. Often, however, support fire was restricted by logistical problems associated with directing long-range naval fire onto inland targets. Ameliorating these problems with better radio and satellite communications as well as modern fire control systems results in increased effectiveness of naval ground support fire and a carrier air group’s ground attack capabilities.

Surface escort formations must balance protection against various threats from air, surface, and subsurface combatants. A formation that optimizes one over the other will take a different shape than a formation that seeks to balance protection against all. The objective of any formation is to provide overlapping fire and support from all friendly forces in the formation by taking into account weapon range and effectiveness, crew capability, and combatant mobility.

Carrier strike group (CSG) doctrine organizes a naval force around the aircraft carrier in order to complement the carrier’s strengths and mitigate its weaknesses. Typically, a CSG’s carrier and its air wing provides the primary offensive firepower for the group, which also includes at least one cruiser for anti-ship missile support and air defense, and at least one destroyer or frigate squadron for supplementary anti-ship missile support, air defense, and anti-submarine warfare capability.

The strength of a carrier battle group is its air wing’s ability to detect and strike the enemy at long range, so maintaining constant airborne reconnaissance screen enables the group to spot enemy assets long before they come into attack range. Early detection enables the carrier group to take appropriate defensive measures against unexpected threats, and generally increases the group’s combat power.

A fleet’s range is dependent on its ability to stay supplied. Smaller ships that must use most of their space for weapons and ship systems are especially reliant on regular resupply, and non-nuclear propelled ships must take on addition fuel frequently. By developing sophisticated schedules and procedures to coordinate navy-wide fleet supply, logistical inefficiency can be eliminated in order to extend ship range.

Spotting the enemy is the first step to destroying him, and efficiently detecting enemy assets from the air requires a systematic approach to airborne patrolling. Patrol patterns work to supplement the fleet’s own sensors and attempt to cover as much area with as few aircraft as possible. Furthermore, better organization of search craft enables a carrier to respond much more efficiently to any enemy contacts and gives more warning prior to an attack.

‘Scrambling’ aircraft is the process of getting an aircraft airborne in as short a time as possible to respond to an impending threat. The sooner an aircraft can get in the air, the better chance it has of neutralizing the threat and protecting its carrier battle group. The best way to ensure short scramble times is to constantly drill ground crews and pilots in the procedure of launching aircraft for flight in order to build efficiency.

One of the surface escort ship’s most important roles is anti-submarine warfare. Escorts possess limited options for engaging subsurface threats so procedures for patrol and engagement of enemy submarines must be established as standard procedure to maximize their effectiveness. For instance, an escort will bomb the last known location of a submarine, moving outward from its point of detection in a pattern designed to encompass the submarine’s most likely escape route.

Often, a swarm of smaller ships can overpower a few large ones by focusing their efforts against the larger ships. By presenting numerous targets to the enemy vessels, the small ships can cause confusion and indecisiveness in the enemy fleet that they can exploit in a rapid attack. Similarly, numerous small ships working together can overwhelm submarine threats by saturating an area with anti-submarine munitions. This doctrine institutionalizes these principles into a cohesive whole.

Coastal defense doctrine focuses on the use of numerous small missile boats to maximize the offensive capabilities of missiles weapons. Because missiles can be mounted on small craft, a coastal defense navy may field great numbers of these boats to meet threats with a flurry of missile fire. Coastal defense doctrine requires land-based aircraft and radar to support the surface fleet’s action because the vessels themselves have space for little more than their own armaments.

A response ready group is a designated group of escort vessels that engages any enemy assents that threaten the group with attack. By assigning this role to a select group of vessels, response times are lessened and the vessels are able to train specifically for that mission, increasing effectiveness in combat. The use of response ready groups increases a fleet’s overall resilience to attack.

Escorts for missile-centered surface action groups perform the critical functions of air-defense and detection, scouting for enemy surface contacts, and detecting and engaging enemy submarines. Because a surface action group lacks the air scouting and strike capabilities of a carrier battle group, its escorts must perform those functions. This typically calls for the escorts to screen the main strike group at some distance in order to prevent its detection and destruction.
Deny Enemy Freedom of Action Doctrine

Missile combat depends on reserving one’s main strike group until the enemy’s disposition favors a missile attack against him. Attacking when the enemy is able to defend against it will expend the attack without effect and betray the location of one’s own main strike formation. However, an attacker can create favorable conditions by deploying fleet assets to deny the enemy free use of the battle space, thereby funneling him into a location where force can be concentrated against him.

Because a modern aircraft carrier represents the majority of a carrier battle group’s offensive capability, knocking one out is the primary objective of its enemies. Although the carrier’s air power usually outclasses a missile-based group in terms of range, the missile-armed ships may take advantage of their capability of volume of fire by rushing the carrier group in a rapid maneuver to engage. Such a maneuver carries high risk, but where the payoff is a sunk aircraft carrier, the risk may be worth the cost.

The ocean provides a ready means of attacking the coast to those who possess amphibious capabilities, but to develop the ability to attack from the water, a nation must invest heavily in training and materiel of amphibious warfare. Specialized landing craft are essential to an amphibious assault, as is coordination with a nation’s fleet for fire support. Moreover, amphibious operations are logistically very complex and can fail due to their own inherent inefficiency if they are not carefully and competently managed.

Inter-service operability refers to the capability of one naval force to provide logistic or administrative support to another navy. The efficiency of inter-service operability depends on the standardization that the two navies share in common, from type of fuel used to sophisticated electronic components. Allied navies with high inter-service operability enjoy logistical benefits when operating in tandem.

A fleet command system is an administrative body whose mission is to organize, man, train, and equip a nation’s naval forces, and to defeat the nation’s enemies at sea. The doctrine sets a system of optimal allocation of naval resources in the form of vessels to combatant commanders under the authority of the nation’s government.

The establishment of a naval logistics command that jointly organizes fleet supply lines greatly benefits a nation’s naval capability. The doctrine is an advanced developed system with an architecture for advanced management and allocation of fleet ordnance and supply. The capabilities provided by the naval logistics command enable fleets to operate further from supply depots for longer durations of time.

The doctrine of self sustainment or self-sufficiency seeks to enhance the capability of naval forces to maintain themselves by independent effort and lengthen the fraction of time in which the naval system can sustain itself. This will increase the quality of each vessels independence and survivability without external support.

By establishing a standard of systems compatibility, the naval command structure becomes more flexible and modifications to naval systems can be completed with greater ease. This system design is aimed to avoid situations where the naval system ends up in what is called 'breaking changes,' or where the modification of one part of a system causes the other parts to fail, and thus adaptability is greatly increased across navies.

Practicing warlike training keeps readiness high and attuned to the realities of war by emphasizing realistic simulations of actual combat. The philosophy of warlike training is to ‘train as you fight and to fight as you train.’ In practice, this entails subjecting crews and commanders to simulated engagements where they must perform their duties in a high stress and chaotic environment.

Contingency plans dictate a naval force’s response to outcomes of naval operations that diverge from the expected outcome of a naval operation. The main aim of contingency planning is to maintain a high readiness for the unexpected and to institutionalize standing policies to mitigate potentially disastrous impacts on naval forces. During times of crisis, contingency plans are often developed to explore and prepare for any eventuality.

A critical vulnerability in a system is any vulnerability whose destruction has the potential of collapsing the entire system. Therefore, identifying and attacking an enemy’s critical vulnerabilities is of prime interest to naval commanders. In the context of naval warfare, a fleet’s critical vulnerability is usually its command ship. On the defensive, critical vulnerability management is the systematic practice of identifying, classifying, remediating, and mitigating critical naval vulnerabilities.

The complexities of underwater naval combat requires navies to develop standard procedures to simplify the process of attacking vessels while submerged. For instance, a submarine must spot, engage, and launch its torpedoes by relying only on instrumentation from sonar and other sensors, the accuracy of which will determine the success of its missile or torpedo salvoes. The submarine must then evade the enemy’s inevitable attempts to located and destroy it in retaliation for the attack.

Paring attack submarines with ballistic missile ‘boomer’ submarines allows the attack submarine to use its advanced sensor suite, strike capabilities, and countermeasures to provide additional protection to the boomer. In the event that one of the pair are detected, the attack submarine can act to divert attention from the boomer in order to allow it to remain hidden or destroy enemy vessels that threaten it.

Submarines make excellent escorts and screens for surface action groups and carrier battle groups because of their stealth capabilities and advanced sensor suites. They are able to both act alone in spotting and engaging threats to the surface fleet or in conjunction with it to destroy the enemy’s forces. Successful integration of submarines into an escort role requires the development of procedures to allow a submarine to efficiently receive orders and report intelligence to the fleet commander.

Submarine service is characterized by extremely long periods of boredom. Especially in boomer service, crews must be kept ready to perform a nuclear launch that, if everything goes according to plan, will never occur. To maintain their fighting edge, submarine crews must train continuously be ready to switch from mundane operations to high combat tempo. Additionally, ship equipment must be kept in the same state of high readiness through constant upkeep and maintenance.

With the advent of nuclear submarines that can remain submerged for months, subsurface warfare increasingly becomes a contest between which side can interpret its sensory data most competently. By emphasizing the technical aspects of submarine warfare and training commanders to make the best use of their submarine’s sensors, navies can increase the chance of detecting enemy naval assets.

Because of their unique mission requirements, submarines necessarily have limited contact with theatre commanders and therefore must rely on their own situational awareness to make decisions autonomously. Satellite communications allow a submarine to stay in greater contact with HQ because it removes the need to remain in radio range. Greater contact with central command allows submarine commanders to receive the latest intelligence, increasing their combat effectiveness.

Submarines reach their full potential when operating for extended periods on their own. They may be inserted into a theatre of war weeks or months in advance in order to perform reconnaissance operations and assist surface operations. In order to operate autonomously, submarines must be stocked with sufficient food and fuel to last for months without resupply. Finding space for the extra provisions can be challenging given the restricted space inside a submarine.

Submarines historically operated as ‘lone wolves,’ hunting enemy surface vessels completely unsupported. However, post-WWII advances in radar and communications changed naval warfare to allow the integration of submarines into a larger fleet’s communications network. By providing submarine commanders with intelligence from aircraft, surface vessels, other submarines, and stationary sensors, their ability to engage the enemy is greatly enhanced.

In combat beneath the waves, sound is sight and silence is invisibility. A submarine may use active sonar to reveal the position of enemy craft, but it will also betray the submarine’s own position to any enemy who is listening in. Therefore, submarines use passive sonar for clues about the presence of enemy vessels. The other side of the coin, to defeat the enemy’s passive sonar and remain invisible, is to eliminate all noises associated with an operating submarine by ‘running silent.’

First strike capability refers to the ability of a nuclear ballistic missile-equipped submarine fleet to execute a nuclear strike against an enemy before that enemy has struck with his own nuclear weapons. Second strike capability refers to the capability of a submarine fleet to launch a retaliatory nuclear strike after an enemy has already executed his own nuclear strike. These capabilities are critical for a nation’s submarine fleet to act as a deterrence in a mutually-assured destruction scenario.

Offensive air superiority aims to win supremacy in the skies with fighters in order to guarantee air support for ground operations, bombing campaigns, air supply missions, paratroop assaults, etc. Completing this mission requires fighter aircraft to engage enemy fighters and other aircraft in order to deny them the use of the sky, thus clearing the way for other friendly aircraft.

Interceptor aircraft are designed to engage incoming enemy bombers or other aircraft upon detection by long range radar. They represent an extreme emphasis on flight ceiling and maximum speed, often suffering from short range and poor handling characteristics as a result. Although critical to counter the threat of nuclear-armed strategic bombers, interceptors historically receded in significance with the advent of ICBMs whose speed rendered them invulnerable to interception.

A ‘Wild Weasel’ is an aircraft equipped to find and destroy enemy surface-to-air missile (SAM) sites. Groups of wild weasels work as a team to draw a targeting lock from a SAM site in order to identify its location and coordinate its destruction with air-to-ground missiles. More advanced weapons incorporate anti-radiation technology that follows the SAM’s radar beam from the air to its source. Wild weasel missions require specialized tactics and expertise to execute effectively.

Ground-directed bombing, also known as army-directed bombing, is a method of performing airstrikes by directing ground attack aircraft to their targets from land-based ground support in radio contact with the aircraft. Ground support stations may guide the aircraft to the target visually, but usually command guidance is achieved with the use of tracking radars and maps. Ground-directed bombing allows for bombing missions at night and in poor weather conditions.

An airbridge is the route and means of delivering material from one place to another by an airlift. The technique is used when the most efficient or only available means of delivering goods to a destination is by air, usually when the destination is isolated in hostile territory. Airbridge operations may also supplement conventional rail, road, or water transport. Marshalling enough supplies and aircraft to sustain an army or city requires immense logistical and technical expertise and is extremely costly.

This technology encompasses the development of logistics planning for helicopter airlift operations. The vertical takeoff and landing capability of rotary wing aircraft make them extremely adept at delivering supplies to otherwise inaccessible locations. Moreover, helicopter resupply is more precise than parachute dropping supplies, and helicopters can also pick up materiel and personnel for evacuation if needed. However, rotary wing aircraft suffer from shorter range than their fixed wing counterparts.

Mobile Army Surgical Hospital (MASH) is a program designed to get experienced medical personnel closer to the front in order to treat wounded sooner and more successfully. Under the MASH program, casualties are first treated at the point of injury by a fellow comrade or medic then delivered to an emergency aid station for stabilizing surgery. Finally, the stabilized casualty is transferred to the MASH for the most extensive treatment. The use of helicopters is critical to the effectiveness of the MASH system.

Aerial reconnaissance missions must be executed with very high precision, necessitating extensive planning and expertise by both pilots and ground personnel. If a pilot cannot successfully gather the required intelligence on the first flyover, either due to missing the target or adverse weather conditions, additional potentially hazardous recon missions must be flown to achieve success. Planning and execution are therefore critical to successful aerial intelligence gathering.

Airborne early warning and control (AEW&C), also known as airborne warning and control system (AWACS), is the technology and application of methods for detecting enemy elements in a battle space and controlling friendly elements operating in the battle space with the use of aircraft. Extensive protocols and procedures govern AEW&C operations, ensuring that they can respond to all threats posed by the enemy and adapt to rapidly changing modern battlefields.

Post-WWII anti submarine warfare (ASW) operations involve numerous platforms capable of detecting and engaging enemy submarines, such as ships, attack submarines, helicopters, and fixed wing aircraft. Integrating these new platforms into an effective ASW system requires the development of new ASW doctrines that emphasize the ability of any ASW platform to immediately engage detected submarines.

The unity of command principle means that each subordinate unit reports to only one superior. In classical organization theory, the lines of authority and command in an organizational structure ensure clear assignment of duties because of the clarity of authority relationships within the system. The utilization of chain of command ensures that the principle of unity of command is maintained.

Defining a specific objective, such as destruction of an installation or air superiority over a certain region, and concentrating military effort toward achieving that objective is critical for effective use of air assets. This doctrine encompasses the ascertainment of objectives that will cripple the enemy’s will and ability to fight and the methods for focusing air power to attain these objectives.

The offensive principle is a military doctrine that seeks to seize, retain, and exploit the initiative through aggressive projection of force in order to attain an objective or achieve some larger strategic, operational, or tactical goal. An air offensive doctrine in general focuses on attack by any number of different types of operations, usually employing specialized types of aircraft.

The concentration of superior force at a critical point, usually via the use of strategic bombing, is a methodology distinct from both tactical bombing and the use of strategic air assets in an operational capacity. This ‘mass’ doctrine stresses the need to overwhelm the enemy with sufficiently large tonnage of ordinance to render him unable to resist.

The maneuver principle is a doctrine that stresses efficient deployment of air assets to achieve surprise and force concentration against the enemy. The doctrine aims to place the enemy at a disadvantage with deft maneuvers of assets to ascertain and then attack his weak points. To achieve this, forces must be held in a high state of readiness at all times and be extremely flexible to adapt to changing battlefield situations.

The economy of force principle calls for the rational use of force by selecting the best mix of combat power. To ensure overwhelming combat power is available, minimal combat power should be devoted to secondary objectives. At the operational level, this requires minimum effort be made towards secondary objectives that do not support the larger operational or strategic objectives.

The security principle is the doctrine of setting up aerial logistical bases with a secured perimeter, usually in the form of a military airbase. Sometimes referred to as a military airfield, military airport, air force station, or air force base, these aerial logistical bases are used as security nodes for operational bases for supply drop missions, air bridges, and medevac, and as bases for other operations aimed towards both civilian and military targets.

The surprise principle is a doctrine that emphasizes attacks that take the enemy off guard and give the attacker an advantage arising from the enemy’s confusion and inability to act. For instance, striking the enemy in a position he feels is secure, misleading the enemy to believe that he has the advantage and attacking when he overextends himself, etc. are example applications of the surprise principle.

The simplicity principle advocates the deployment of a class of ships whose primary purpose is to launch helicopters and short take-off and vertical landing aircraft. These types of aircraft are able to carry out a very wide range of missions and perform different roles, and by simplifying logistics by tying them to a single platform, a military can conduct many operations normally relegated to carrier fleets at a fraction of the cost.

Typically carried out by helicopters, search and rescue (SAR) missions can be some of the most dangerous missions performed by any air force in the world. Often they involve venturing into hostile weather conditions or enemy territory and taking great risks in recovering the victim. Consequently, specialized training and procedures must be developed to enable SAR capability.

Precision bombing refers to bombing practices that seek to limit collateral damage to surrounding structures or people, for example, the destruction of a single building amidst a built-up urban landscape. Precision bombing requires both advanced technology and a high degree of skill, especially when employing ‘dumb,’ i.e. unguided, bombs. Procedures and training for precision bombing are intensive and require a high degree of proficiency to execute in combat.

Area bombing is a form of strategic bombing that is supposed to divert an enemy's industrial and military resources from the primary battlefield to air defense. The doctrine calls for attack an enemy’s cities in order to force him to commit resources in defense. Area bombing is also an effective way of destroying enemy industry and infrastructure, but it requires large masses of bombers flying in tight formations. Crews must be trained in how to maintain formation and deliver their payload onto the target area.

Precision guided missiles, or 'smart' weapons, enable a projectile to home in to its target and frees the operator from the need to fire the weapon according to a ballistic trajectory. Smart capability increases the kill ratio of the attacking aircraft for air-to-air missiles and the precision of air-to-ground munitions. However, pilots must be trained in methods for effective deployment of these weapons to ensure their efficacy in combat.

Low level operations involve low altitude insertions and extractions typically associated with special forces. Flying low to the ground helps aircraft evade radar and visual detection, and it helps the pilot locate the designated landing zone. Low level flight is much more dangerous than normal flight, full of its own peculiar hazards and surprises, and it requires specialized pilot training to perform effectively in combat.

After WWII, air forces of many countries developed a more comprehensive system of pilot training, including simulated dogfights designed to test pilot responses in an actual combat setting. Expanding these exercises to simulate ground strikes, search and rescue, anti-submarine warfare, etc. is an invaluable training tool for building pilot skill.

This doctrine encompasses the use of airborne forces, usually light infantry, moveable by aircraft and 'dropped' into battle. Thus they can be placed behind enemy lines and have the capability to deploy almost anywhere with little warning. The formations are limited only by the number and size of their aircraft, so if a combatant is able to organize sufficient capacity a huge force can appear 'out of nowhere' in minutes, an action referred to as 'vertical envelopment.'

Air assault is the movement of ground-based military forces by vertical take-off and landing (VTOL) aircraft, such as by helicopter, to seize and hold key terrain which has not been fully secured and to directly engage enemy forces. Planning air assault operations requires the consideration of the terrain to be attacked, the terrain that must be flown over to reach the destination, and the strength of the enemy at the target. Furthermore, air crews and infantry muse be well-trained to efficiently execute an air assault.

Paratroopers are soldiers, marines, and other infantry forces trained in parachuting into an operation and usually function as part of an airborne force. They are used for tactical advantage because they can be inserted into the battlefield from the air, allowing them access to areas not accessible by land. Paratroopers require extensive, specialized training in the specific skills necessary to complete their mission.

Air cavalry refers to units that specialize in air assault from vertical takeoff and landing aircraft. Units of this type may also be referred to as 'Airmobile,' or with other terms that describe the integration of air and ground combat forces within a single unit. Air cavalry is capable of striking far behind enemy lines in order to interdict enemy movement, exploit an enemy’s weakness, or support a unit that has become cut off from friendly forces.

‘Small arms’ is a term that refers generally to any man-portable, direct fire infantry weapon that is not a support weapon. This includes battle rifles, assault rifles, squad automatic rifles, light machine guns, pistols, and sniper rifles. The line between small arms and support weapons can become blurry and largely semantic: a military shotgun is technically a support weapon because it fills a specialized niche in combat. Most militaries do not consider medium and larger machine guns to be small arms.

Explosives possess a wide range of military applications. From more efficient and cleaner rifle cartridge propellants, to lighter high explosives for bombs and missiles, explosives stand at the heart of modern warfare. Innovations in explosive technology involve the control of the blast so that its energy is focused against a small point, thus enhancing penetration. Explosives technology is also directly related to the effectiveness of anti-armor weapons such as anti-tank artillery, rocket, and missile weapons.

A crew-served weapon system is any weapon system that requires more than one soldier (a crew) to operate due to its complexity. Man-portable crew-served weapons include medium and heavy machine guns, mortars, recoilless rifles, shoulder-launched anti-tank and anti-aircraft missile launchers, etc. Heavier crew-served weapons include artillery guns, anti-tank and anti-air guns, direct fire guns mounted on vehicles, and heavy mortars.

Small combustion engines are used to power small vehicles like motorcycles. Their small capacity does not allow much power, but they are light enough to be easily portable. Besides their motorcycle application, light engines are typically used in a myriad of utility roles such as power generation and industrial applications.

Larger engines can power larger vehicles like cars and tractors, but they are too heavy to be portable like a light engine. The United States historically based its medium engines on those developed by its automobile industry, whereas the Soviet Union based its engine design on tractor technology. These engines are very powerful and comparatively lightweight, making them the most widespread vehicle engine in the world.

Truly heavy engines are massive power plants capable of propelling a Main Battle Tank up to 65 Km/h (40 mph). Engines of this class displace up to 25,000 cc and develop 1,200 – 1,500 hp. The price of this power is weight and fuel consumption. More advanced engines will be both lighter and more fuel efficient, rendering their vehicles faster and capable of covering more ground before refueling.

Light armor is capable of stopping only small arms fire, such as rifle rounds and heavy machine gun (12.7mm/50 cal.) rounds. It can also withstand shrapnel from artillery bursts, but not much else. Vehicles equipped with light armor have the advantage of light weight, making them more portable and able to be delivered to hard-to-reach battlefields. When the only alternative to a lightly-armored vehicle is no vehicle at all, the former is vastly preferable.

Medium armor is capable of stopping hits from up to small-bore AT rounds. It can protect from artillery shrapnel and is resistant to direct hits. However, most rocket AT weapons will penetrate medium armor without much trouble. Medium armor strives to strike a balance between protection and weight: it is commonly found on APCs and any other combat vehicles that do not boast a large, powerful engine. Vehicles equipped with medium armor are not as portable or mobile as light armored vehicles.

Heavy armor is generally reserved for main battle tanks. It is intended to defeat multiple strikes from high-velocity armor-piercing rounds and keep the crew and vehicle operational. Heavy armor is not just thicker steel: it uses layers of composites and other materials designed specifically to defeat the enemy’s armor-piercing technology. Vehicles with heavy armor are intended to meet the deadliest enemy units in open battle and kill them, paving the way for lighter forces.

Anti-tank warfare arose with the first use of tanks in WWI and has been evolving to counter advances in armor ever since. Anti-tank rifles, grenades, and even rifle fire were sufficient to disable early tanks, but the only enduring anti-tank weapons have been rocket, mine, and – to a lesser extent – conventional gun systems. Anti-tank weapons must constantly keep pace with armor technology while remaining light enough to be useful in combat.

Radar detects objects by emitting radio or microwave signals and detecting the electromagnetic ‘echo’ when these waves bounce off a solid object. It can detect any object within range, from surface ships to orbiting spacecraft. Advances in radar technology increase: the radar’s range, their filtering ability to noise and clutter in the signal, miniaturizing the equipment, and can better deal with electronic countermeasures such as jamming.

Light anti-aircraft (AA) weapons are quick to deploy and easy to transport even in rough terrain. Light AA guns are very quick-firing because of their small bore diameter but they lack the punch of larger cannon. More modern AA systems rely on radar-guided or heat-seeking missile technology to home in on enemy aircraft. Often these systems are shoulder-fired, but larger systems are used to defend fixed positions. Light AA is useful because of its mobility: it is not a substitute for larger AA weapons systems.

Medium anti-aircraft (AA) weapons are more effective than light AA. However, they are less mobile: larger guns and missiles must be towed into place and set up prior to firing, requiring larger crews and more logistical support. Consequently, poor roads and rough terrain adversely affect medium AA systems. More modern medium AA systems are mounted on vehicles and employ integrated radar systems to track air targets. However, added complexity also adds a greater risk of equipment failure.

Heavy anti-aircraft (AA) weapons represent the most effective air defense systems available. They generally require extensive setup, so much so that most heavy AA systems are essentially static installations. Modern systems have evolved into a network of missile defense sites, each with its own tracking radar array, that can communicate signals to one another and detect even low-signature aircraft. Also, heavy AA weapons are the only ones capable of reaching into the upper atmosphere.

Main battle tanks (MBTs) are a class of modern tank that is meant to replace the light, medium, and heavy tanks of post-WWII armies. The ability of medium tanks to carry 100mm and larger guns capable of penetrating any vehicle armor then in use necessitated the development of advanced composite and ceramic armors fitted to massively-powerful tanks that could withstand combat with similar vehicles. Thus, the MBT was born. MBTs are also designed to resist nuclear, chemical, and biological weapon attacks.

Rocket engines can achieve the highest amount of thrust in the shortest time, and are also lighter than any other type of engine. However, they consume the most fuel. Rocket engines burn either liquid or solid propellant. Liquid propellant allows a rocket to have low-volume and low-pressure propellant tanks, lightening the propulsion system and allowing higher payload. However, liquid propellant rockets are complex and prone to failure. Solid-fuel rockets by contrast are more inert and comparatively simple.

Modern rocket artillery arose in WWII, where the German and Soviet armies used it extensively in land warfare, and the U.S. Navy, for shore bombardment. Rocket artillery is more mobile than conventional artillery, it can deliver more explosives at once than an artillery gun, and it has superior range. However, conventional artillery guns are more durable than rocket systems, artillery rounds are cheaper to mass-produce, and conventional artillery can sustain a bombardment for far longer than any rocket system.

Missiles must possess an effective targeting system to find their target and sufficient range to reach it, a precise guidance system, and sufficient explosive power to destroy the target. Missile designs include cruise missiles, which use airfoils to fly themselves to the target, and ballistic missiles, which rely on Newtonian physics. Missiles are a very versatile weapons platform and can fulfill anti-ship, -tank, -air, -missile, and -satellite roles. They can be fired from the surface, air, subsurface, and even from orbit.

The combat engineer is a class of solider that specializes in construction and demolition in combat conditions. Engineers typically have anti-armor capabilities, but they specialize in fortifying positions, building roads and bridges, and destroying the enemy’s counterparts. Their mission therefore requires that combat engineers be highly skilled in the use of specialized equipment, tools, and vehicles. These include everything from wrenches and bulldozers to demolition charges and flamethrower tanks.

Amphibious capability encompasses the equipment, training, and tactics needed to effectively operate in water. WWII famously saw extensive offensive landings by troops from the ocean, but amphibious warfare also includes the organic ability of units to ford rivers without additional support and the ability to use water to offensive advantage. Amphibious units are able to negate the traditional barrier that rivers and lakes present to land forces, rendering such units very useful in mobile warfare.

Jungle environments challenge military operations on a number of levels. Extremely dense vegetation limits lines of sight, compelling forces to fight at close range. Furthermore vehicles are extremely ill-suited to jungles, and disease spreads rapidly, as well. Unite operating in a jungle environment require extensive training, and gear must be modified to ensure proper operation in the heat and humidity. Otherwise, metal parts rust, mud clogs mechanical devices, and optics uselessly fog up.

Mountain warfare comprises the skills and equipment necessary for a unit to function in mountainous or rugged terrain. Not only must troops battle steep vertical inclines, they must also survive extreme weather, lightning strikes, and exposure of combat in the mountains. Movement in mountains is extremely difficult, so only the lightest and handiest equipment is suitable for use there. However, equipment properly adapted for use in mountains will be a force multiplier for units using it.

Desert warfare requires specialized training and equipment to deal with the unique demands of a desert environment. The adverse conditions most prominent in the desert are extreme temperature fluctuations, extreme scarcity of water, low humidity, and intense solar radiation during the day. These conditions necessitate specialized training and equipment for units operating in the desert. Units without desert warfare capability can expect their effectiveness to plunge when exposed to a desert environment.

The extreme cold of arctic conditions takes a severe toll on equipment and personnel. Motor vehicles not designed or modified to operate in arctic conditions will fail when exposed to them. Similarly, infantry must be equipped with skis, cleats, or snowshoes to navigate arctic terrain and require highly specialized gear just to survive the elements. Often, the better-equipped side in an arctic environment will gain the upper hand simply by retaining their ability to function in the extreme conditions.

Personal body armor in the form of the ‘flak jacket’ was used extensively by WWII bomber and ship crews to protect from artillery shell fragments. These used ballistic nylon and steel plates in a brigandine configuration. Advances in plastics and synthetic materials allowed armored vests to be worn by infantry, but these garmets were still quite heavy. Not until the emergence of superstrong materials like Kevlar, composites, and ceramics did infantry body armor truly become viable in ground combat.

Night vision goggles (NVGs) are a subset within the broader class of night vision devices (NVDs). Although night vision devices–including thermal imaging and image intensifiers–are relatively easily incorporated into vehicle optics, the technology to miniaturize and power NVGs is very difficult to perfect. However, militaries that are able to equip their soldiers with NVGs wield an incredible advantage over those who cannot: the ability to turn night into day and operate while the enemy is blind.

Battlefield medicine is the technology, organization, and procedures used to care for individuals wounded in battle. Typically, this involves specialized soldiers (‘medics’) that immediately stabilize a casualty who is then transported to a field hospital staffed with more extensively trained personnel. After that, the casualty is transferred to a hospital to fully recover. Advances in battlefield medicine enables more extensive care to be given to casualties closer to the time of their wounding, thus saving more lives.

Light artillery comprises guns with a small bore diameter that fire a relatively small round. Light artillery’s lack of punch relegated it to the sidelines during WWII, where it proved incapable of defeating most armored vehicles. However, the many armies equip their light and mountain infantry with light artillery because these troops appreciate its light weight and small dimensions. Modern automatic cannons have their roots in light artillery: these weapons are useful for arming light armored vehicles.

Medium artillery comprises guns with intermediate bore diameter, roughly from 6cm to 10cm. This bore classification encompasses the majority of artillery in service because it strikes a balance between firepower and weight, making it suitable for a variety of roles.
