Medium artillery designs are found on howitzers, towed field guns, self-propelled guns, tanks, anti-tank guns, infantry guns, and mortars.

The largest artillery cannon–10cm and up–are used only when firepower trumps all other concerns like weight and maneuverability. Heavy artillery is very useful on the battlefield: in WWII, cannons of this type served as tank-destroyers and huge 15cm versions were used in armored vehicles to demolish enemy strong points. Heavy artillery is especially useful in siege situations. In terms of destructiveness, only strategic bombing and nuclear weapons can match a sustained heavy artillery barrage.

Vehicle armor must always balance weight against protection: a vehicle with super heavy armor, although invulnerable, cannot adequately maneuver in battle. Advanced armors keep weight low by applying ballistics and materials science to defeat specific types of attacks. Modern materials such as composites and reactive armor can defeat powerful attacks, but low-tech applications of, for instance, slat armor can also provide excellent protection against certain types of attacks.

Carriers have retained their central role since WWII, although supercarriers eventually became the queens of sea. Many navies chose to buy and modernize a WWII carrier to suit their requirements. Carriers built in the Cold War era were generally smaller, used conventional propulsion, and were equipped with sky-jump decks for VTOL/STOVL aircraft. Despite being outclassed by the much larger supercarriers, carriers still provide a significant naval strike capability.

‘Supercarrier’ is an unofficial term first used in 1938, but modern supercarriers are considered to be any aircraft carrier that displaces more than 70,000 tons. Supercarriers carry an air wing of over 70 aircraft, giving them an unprecedented strike capability. Moreover, their nuclear propulsion allows them to reach speeds previously only attainable by much smaller vessels like cruisers and destroyers, making the supercarrier not only a very powerful platform, but a very swift one as well.

The game’s catchall term 'helicopter carrier' consolidates ships that fit the description of large helicopter carriers, amphibious attack ships, and aviation cruisers into a single category: i.e. all ships that have a relatively large helicopter wing providing anti-submarine protection or using attack helicopters/VTOL planes to support invasions and land units. These ships and lack the capability to launch conventional aircraft but nevertheless perform a valuable role in many nations’ navies.

Large capital ships, cruisers fulfilled the naval role of scouting out the enemy’s location while battleships dominated the oceans. However, with the advent of radar, sonar, carriers and radio during WWII, the significance of the cruiser as well as the battleship class diminished markedly. Heavy cruisers and battlecruisers disappeared after WWII, but some light cruisers remained in service. Battleships were either decommissioned or converted to powerful weapons platforms.

Guided missile cruisers are a carrier battle group’s primary escort ship and often fill the role of leader ship for surface action groups. They provide longer range and a greater quantity of missile weapons than missile destroyers. In addition to great anti-air protection, guided missile cruisers can carry a moderate number of anti-ship or land attack missiles. Helicopters, close-in weapon systems (CIWS), and conventional deck guns also augment their utility and firepower.

A nuclear missile cruiser is powered by a nuclear generator that drives a steam turbine. These ships are capable of tremendous speed relative to their displacement, even able to outperform destroyers and frigates. Their speed allows them to easily outpace the latest supercarriers and chase down fleeing surface targets, but these technically complex ships are expensive to build and maintain. Like their conventionally-powered counterparts, nuclear missile cruisers fulfill anti-air, ASW, and anti-ship roles.

The nuclear battlecruiser is an enormous, heavily-armed version of a modern cruiser – nearly the size of a WWI battleship. It is larger and heavier than any surface combatant warship other than the aging battleships of the world’s fleets. Unlike a battleship, the battlecruiser relies on advanced long-range supersonic anti-ship missiles to strike enemy targets. It also lacks the thicker armor that historically characterized the battlecruiser class. In fact, its technical classification is simply 'heavy cruiser.'

Destroyers were developed originally as a response to the threat posed by small, fast torpedo boats to WWI-era capital ships. In the modern day, destroyers fulfill much the same role as before. Destroyers are small warships whose speed enables them to screen a surface action group from the threats posed by small, fast craft. These types of threats normally come from aircraft, submarines, and missile boats. Destroyers of the WWII era relied on depth charges and deck guns to fulfill their mission.

Guided missile destroyers are destroyers that are purpose-built to carry as much missile armament as possible. They normally focus on defense of their surface action group from air attack, leaving anti-submarine operations to other destroyers purpose-built for that mission. Although they focus on killing enemy aircraft, guided missile destroyers are able to perform land attack and anti-submarine missions as well. Larger examples of these vessels even approach the capabilities of guided missile cruisers.

Smaller in size than destroyers, frigates represent an adaptation to missile technology that emphasizes speed and maneuverability over size and armor. Because missiles can sink a ship as large as a supercarrier and punch through the thickest armor, the most effective strategy is to attempt to avoid them. Simultaneously, frigates bristle with missile weaponry and sensors to maximize their own offensive punch. Their offensive capabilities enable these small vessels hit above their weight.

Missile boats are an extreme adaptation to naval missile technology. Previously, the most effective guns were the heaviest and largest, thus necessitating an equally heavy and large ship. Missiles, however, can be mounted on even a very small craft and are more accurate at longer ranges than big guns. Therefore, a large mass of small and nimble – even expendable – missile boats makes more tactical and economic sense than traditional capital ship fleet, especially when fighting just those types of capital ships.

The submarine force was the most effective anti-ship weapon in many navies arsenals at the end of World War II. The primary defense of a submarine lies in its ability to remain concealed in the depths of the ocean. A concealed military submarine is a real threat, and because of its stealth, can force an enemy navy to waste resources searching large areas of ocean and protecting ships against attack. With later development of the homing torpedo, better sonar systems, submarines also could became able to hunt each other as effectively as they did ships.

A teardrop hull is a submarine hull that is designed for optimal hydrodynamic flow while totally submerged, representing a departure from WWII-era submarine designs that emphasized surface performance. Teardrop design lowers a submarine’s acoustic signature, making sonar detection of it more difficult, and gives more room for the submarine’s own sonar equipment, allowing it to hunt enemy submarines and surface vessels while submerged.

An attack submarine is a submarine that is designed specifically to sink other submarines and surface vessels. They are used to screen surface battle groups in naval warfare, as well. Before the advent of nuclear power, submarines operated with diesel-electric propulsion. Diesel engines are used to charge a massive bank of batteries for submerged use. Because diesel engines need air to operate, however, these submarines were limited in their submerged endurance.

Nuclear attack submarines represent a monumental shift in submarine warfare. Nuclear propulsion gives the submarine range limited only by their food storage capacity as well as the novel capability of loitering, submerged and invisible, for months at a time, even under ice caps. Nuclear attack submarines are especially suited to stalking ballistic missile submarines as they roam the oceans. Although primarily armed with torpedoes, newer attack submarines can also launch missiles from their torpedo tubes.

A cruise missile submarine is a submarine that can launch cruise missiles armed with either nuclear or conventional warheads. Diesel electric cruise missile submarines primarily operate on the surface under diesel power, running on electric power only when submerged. They are designed to be stealthy in order to better screen surface action groups and launch surprise attacks against enemy naval forces. Their primary role is anti-ship warfare, but they can use ground-attack cruise missiles as well.

A cruise missile submarine is a submarine that can launch cruise missiles armed with either nuclear or conventional warheads. Nuclear powered cruise missile submarines benefit from the ability to run underwater without ever needing to surface except for food and to replace crews. They are designed to be stealthy in order to better screen surface action groups and launch surprise attacks against enemy naval forces. Their primary role is anti-ship warfare, but they can use ground-attack cruise missiles as well.

Ballistic missile submarines are designed to launch nuclear ballistic missiles at a moment’s notice. These submarines supplement a nation’s strategic capacity to conduct nuclear war by loitering for months in the ocean, standing by for the order to launch their missiles. Ballistic missile submarines are difficult to knock out in a nuclear exchange and provide a strategic second strike capability to nations who field them. They rely on stealth to evade the enemy’s attack submarines, who constantly stalk them.

Steam turbines are fueled by coal or, later, fuel oil or nuclear power. The marine steam turbine is a relatively old technology, developed by Sir Charles Algernon Parsons in 1897. This facilitated a generation of high-speed liners in the first half of the 20th century and rendered the reciprocating steam engine obsolete in warships. Although steam turbines are no longer high-tech in the post-WWII naval world, they are reliable and versatile enough to warrant use by some navies.

In naval power plants, the gas-turbine engine has two advantages over steam- and diesel-driven plants: it is lightweight and compact. Compressed natural gas take up less volume and burns more efficiently than both diesel and fuel for steam engines, and the gas turbine system is more thermally efficient as well. Advanced gas turbine power plants are capable of generating 20,000 horsepower over a period of more than 5,000 hours.

After WWII the diesel and internal combustion engine started to replace the steam engine as the preferred power source for ocean going ships. The engines were more fuel efficient than steam, especially diesel. There was no boiler that was constantly being fired, with a lot of heat loss going up the stack. The diesel engines were adapted to burning the same heavy bunker fuel used by steam engines.

Diesel electric submarines use a direct mechanical connection between the engine and propeller, switching between diesel engines for surface running, and electric motors for submerged propulsion. These submarines must recharge their electric batteries using diesel-powered generators and therefore can only operate submerged for a limited time before they must surface to recharge. Consequently, diesel electric submarines spend most of their time on or very near the surface of the ocean.

A naval nuclear power plant uses a nuclear reactor to heat water, creating steam to drive the engine’s turbines. Due to low prices of diesel oil, nuclear propulsion is rare except in some Navy and specialist vessels such as icebreakers and advanced warships. In large aircraft carriers, the space formerly used for ship's bunkerage could be used instead to bunker aviation fuel. In submarines, the ability to run submerged at high speed and in relative quiet for long periods holds obvious advantages.

Engineers use the lessons learned from the nuclear reactor sea trials to design a production-ready nuclear reactor for use on surface vessels. This enables the construction of nuclear-powered ships that use the nuclear reactor to heat water, creating steam to drive the vessel’s turbines.

Engineers use the lessons learned from the nuclear reactor sea trials to design a production-ready nuclear reactor for use on submarines. This enables the construction of nuclear-powered submarines that use the nuclear reactor to heat water, creating steam to drive the vessel’s turbines.

Sea trials are preliminary tests at sea that are needed for integrating a surface ship’s existing steam turbine power plant to the use heat of from a nuclear reactor. These are proof-of-concept tests designed to find problems in the propulsion system and prove that a nuclear-powered vessel is a practical proposition.

Sea trials are preliminary tests at sea that are needed to put a new class of nuclear reactor-powered submarines into service. These are proof-of-concept tests designed to find problems in the propulsion system and prove that a nuclear-powered submarine is a practical proposition.

A vertical launching system (VLS) stores and fires missiles from a device built onto a ship’s deck. They can carry more missiles, fire faster, and are easier to reload than twin-arm or box launchers. VLS systems also benefit from greater modularity and the ability to be reloaded by a magazine below deck. They also present a smaller radar cross-section than twin-arm or box launchers. A modern VLS container can accept anti-air, anti-sub (ASROC), anti-ship, or land-attack missiles depending on the ship’s mission.

Accurately placing artillery fire on target from an unstable naval platform has always presented a challenge to warship designers. A targeting system must accurately gauge the range to the target, compensate for the movement of the gun platform relative to the target, and correct for atmospheric conditions and even the rotation of the earth at longer ranges. Accurate fire control requires even more precision when engaging fast moving targets like aircraft and missiles.

The first practical design of a submarine-based launch platform was developed near the end of World War II and required vessels to be surfaced when firing their missiles. By adapting the systems to allow underwater launching the survivability of the submarine is greatly enhanced.

Submarine-launched ballistic missiles require an enormous launching system. Furthermore, the complexity of subsurface ballistic missile launchers requires highly skilled engineering and the development of protocols to ensure that launches operate smoothly. Many nations find the strategic value of submarine-launched ballistic missiles to be well-worth the investments in time and money, however.

Heavy torpedoes, by virtue of their size, are capable of traveling further, faster, carrying a much larger punch, and incorporating a more sophisticated guidance system than light torpedoes. However, their large size limits them to only certain types of naval vessels. The space restrictions of submarines especially hinder the use of heavy torpedoes. Mounting these very capable weapons onto existing naval vessels usually requires extensive modification to accept their specialized torpedo tubes.

Standardized external torpedo tubes enable torpedo capability for vessels not designed to carry torpedoes. External tubes are mounted to a vessel’s deck or hull and may be reloadable from an onboard magazine. Some torpedo tubes are mounted on a motorized swivel, allowing them to engage targets without maneuvering the ship. External tubes may carry a single torpedo or accommodate multiple weapons.

Although light torpedoes can be launched from a ship’s deck, heavy torpedoes must be launched from tubes inside a ship’s hull because of their size and weight. Consequently, ship designs must accommodate below the waterline torpedo tubes if the capability is sought. Integrating these tubes into a warship involves the usual engineering challenges of restricted space and the need to protect explosive ordinance from attack.

Close-in weapon systems (CIWS) are generally based on a 20-30mm multi-barreled Gatling gun with radar and/or television tracking. They are very effective against aircraft, cruise missiles, and even conventional gun-fired munitions at close range (within 5km), and provide a last bastion of air defense. Modern CIWS are more complex weapon systems incorporating a Gatling gun and a short-range missile launcher working in tandem. Depending from the ship size/class, navies employ 1-8 CIWS mounts on a single ship.

Naval artillery as the primary strike weapon in naval combat reached its zenith in WWI, but after WII it had become clear that the future of naval armaments lay with air power or missile technology. However, naval artillery fulfills a vital fire support role for warships, and developments in naval artillery easily translate to advanced close-in weapon systems (CIWS) applications. Moreover, naval artillery is often the only effective armament for brownwater and greenwater vessels whose primary mission is to provide ground support fire.

Torpedoes are explosive devices capable of traveling underwater on their own power to impact their target. Basic torpedoes are unguided, but advanced models are able to seek out targets by listening for propeller or engine noises. Torpedoes can be installed on nearly any combat platform, from small ASW helicopters and torpedo boats to the largest battleships. Torpedoes are limited by their relatively slow speed that allows a target vessel to detect the attack and take evasive action.

Early anti-ship cruise missiles mainly had short ranges but have remained relevant into the modern day primarily for smaller ships and boats that cannot accommodate larger long-range missiles. Western navies mainly used subsonic turbojet propelled versions, but the Soviet Navy focused on supersonic rocket or ramjet propelled models.

Long range anti-ship missiles were mainly used by the Soviet Navy, with the exception of the naval version of Tomahawk cruise missile which is also classified as long-range. Western navies mainly used subsonic turbojet propelled versions, but the Soviet Navy focused on supersonic rocket or ramjet propelled models.

Anti-submarine missiles allow long-range engagement of enemy submarines. A missile will carry its depth charge or torpedo on a ballistic trajectory toward the target’s position, as fixed by ship sonar, and release its payload once in close proximity. The payload will then guide itself to the target and detonate when in range. Besides their long range, anti-ship missiles have the additional advantage of giving no warning to the target that it is being engaged until the missile’s payload is in the water.

Anti-submarine rockets are depth charges that are propelled by a rocket motor in order to achieve longer ranges than mechanically-launched versions. These weapon systems provide a vessel with close-range anti-submarine capability, with ranges out to about six kilometers (3.7 mi). Their small size allows them to be mounted in cluster launchers on deck and fired in salvoes at submarine threats. An alternative solution to close range submarine defense is to mount depth charges in mortar batteries.

Land attack missiles are a later introduction to the naval arsenal and allow ships and submarines to strike land targets at long range. They use low profile Terrain Contour Matching (TERCOM) or GPS guidance systems, rendering them highly accurate. Later models are capable of advanced loitering and redirecting/reprogramming while in flight. Land attack missiles are fired from box launchers or by vertical launch systems.

Surface-to-air missiles (SAM) are launched from the surface of the land or water to shoot down hostile aircraft. Their extremely high speed enables them to quickly reach their target, giving it very little time to react. Advanced SAMs are able to destroy inbound missiles, as well. Naval surface to air missiles must be built to withstand the harsh conditions of the marine environment. Short range missiles are designed to provide a last bastion of defense against enemy aircraft or missiles that penetrate longer-range defenses.

Surface-to-air missiles (SAM) are launched from the surface of the land or water to shoot down hostile aircraft. Their extremely high speed enables them to quickly reach their target, giving it very little time to react. Advanced SAMs are able to destroy inbound missiles, as well. Naval surface to air missiles must be built to withstand the harsh conditions of the marine environment. Medium range missiles are an upgrade from short range SAMs and are able to provide anti-air defenses at longer ranges.

Surface-to-air missiles (SAM) are launched from the surface of the land or water to shoot down hostile aircraft. Their extremely high speed enables them to quickly reach their target, giving it very little time to react. Advanced SAMs are able to destroy inbound missiles, as well. Naval surface to air missiles must be built to withstand the harsh conditions of the marine environment. Long range SAMs ensure that any air attacks against a fleet encounter resistance from the very outset, seriously disrupting their efficiency.

Missiles are hugely complex devices that are prone to malfunction when subjected to the rigors of combat. Moreover, naval missiles must be robust enough to withstand heavy seas and the corrosive effects of saltwater. The only way to ‘prove’ a missile weapon is with extensive live fire testing at sea. Trials of this kind are designed to discover bugs in the missile and its launch systems in order to make the weapon ready for combat use.

Radar systems designed to detect any air targets including aircraft, helicopters, and missiles. Early 2D air search systems provided only range and bearing data for anti-air missile tracking and guidance systems, and were only capable of acquiring targets in the sky. More advanced air search radars offer more precision and higher resolution of radar contacts.

Radar systems designed to detect surface targets including ships and coastal land objects. They provide targeting data for anti-ship systems, and some versions are also used for navigation and low-flying object detection. As with other radar systems, new surface search radar systems are able to resolve contacts with greater precision than earlier systems.

Three dimensional air search radar differs from standard radar in that it can detect the height of an object above the water in addition to the object’s latitude and longitude. With a maximum range that extends well into the upper atmosphere, three dimensional air search radar is an extremely capable sensor array. Computer processing enables the radar to place the detected object precisely at a point in space and very accurately target the object with anti-air weapons.

Towed array sonar are hydrophones trailed on a long cable behind a ship or submarine. When deployed, they provide distance and directional data, as well as ship classification information using signal processing technologies. The exposed sensor suite is able to provide higher resolution sonar imaging than the submarine's onboard sensors, assisting the sub in acquiring and killing enemy vessels.

Sonar is the underwater equivalent of radar: instead of bouncing radio waves off objects in the air in order to detect their location, sonar bounces sound waves off objects in the water for the same purpose. An object’s sonar signature depends on its size and shape, and sonar is sensitive to particles suspended in the water that cause interference in the signal. Advanced sonar systems are able to mitigate the adverse effects of the marine environment and return a clearer signal to the operator.

The only effective torpedo defense is for a warship to avoid the torpedo altogether or deceive its homing systems into pursuing a decoy target. Consequently, anti-torpedo defenses depend on the development of advanced sensors to allow the warship to take evasive action earlier and countermeasures to throw the torpedo off its track. The efficacy of these systems is heavily dependent on analyzing the behavior of enemy torpedo technology in order to learn how to best defeat them.

Helicopter platforms are landing pads on a ship’s deck that allow the use of antisubmarine warfare (ASW)/Airborn early warning (AEW) helicopters from frigates, destroyers, and cruisers. On smaller ships with limited space, a platform generally gives enough space only for a single helicopter, but larger surface ships can be fitted with a large pad capable of accommodating multiple helicopters. Ships frequently provide hangars for storing additional helicopters and allowing easier service and loading of weapons.

Turbojet engines work by using a gas turbine to compress incoming air, which is then combusted with the help of fuel. The shape of the combustion chamber drives the resulting flame rearward to power the gas turbine and then through a nozzle where it is accelerated to a high speed, thereby propelling the engine forward. Jet engines are able to achieve thrust to weight ratios of 15:1. Small turbojet engines are mainly used on fighters and are designed for high speed.

Turbojet engines work by using a gas turbine to compress incoming air, which is then combusted with the help of fuel. The shape of the combustion chamber drives the resulting flame rearward to power the gas turbine and then through a nozzle where it is accelerated to a high speed, thereby propelling the engine forward. Jet engines are able to achieve thrust to weight ratios of 15:1. Medium turbojet engines are mainly used on fighter and bomber aircraft and are designed for all-around performance.

An afterburner is a device fitted to the rear of a turbojet engine for the purpose of achieving higher thrust, usually for supersonic aircraft. Afterburners spray jet fuel directly into the flame immediately before it reaches the nozzle of a jet engine. This produces a hotter flame and more pressure, and consequently more thrust as the burning gases pass though the engine’s nozzle. Although they boost thrust, afterburners also consume copious amounts of fuel.

Turbojet engines work by using a gas turbine to compress incoming air, which is then combusted with the help of fuel. The shape of the combustion chamber drives the resulting flame rearward to power the gas turbine and then through a nozzle where it is accelerated to a high speed, thereby propelling the engine forward. Jet engines are able to achieve thrust to weight ratios of 15:1. Large turbojet engines are used on heavy bombers and are designed to allow maximum payload and long range.

The airframe of an aircraft is its mechanical structure, usually fuselage, wings, and undercarriage. Early airframes were wooden, but by the 1930s most designs had become all-metal. However, the increased speed of turboprop and jet aircraft challenged to airframe designers to produce stronger and lighter airframes still. Modern jet aircraft wings needed to be both light and very strong to take advantage of the jet engine’s potential for supersonic speed, but finding this balance proved to be extremely difficult.

The airframe of an aircraft is its mechanical structure, usually fuselage, wings, and undercarriage. Early airframes were wooden, but by the 1930s most designs had become all-metal. However, the increased speed of turboprop and jet aircraft challenged to airframe designers to produce stronger and lighter airframes still. Jet transport and bomber aircraft emphasize lifting power over raw speed, requiring a very specialized type of wing.

A helicopter is a type of aircraft that uses rotors to provide lift and thrust and is able to take off and land vertically, hover, and fly forwards, backwards, and laterally. Helicopters excel in areas without prepared landing strips and in tight terrain. However, they are mechanically complex and are inherently sensitive to dirt and debris. Therefore, extensive development is needed to design military helicopters able to function in combat conditions.

As jet engines propelled aircraft faster than ever before, aeronautical engineers realized that the density of air changes when it comes into contact with a moving object. At high velocities, this creates a buildup of high and low densities of air, resulting in a shockwave that can tear airplanes apart. The science of aerodynamics seeks to understand this phenomenon in order to better design supersonic aircraft.

Avionics are all electronic systems used on aircraft, satellites, and spacecraft. Avionics are especially important for military aircraft because they must operate in adverse conditions, deliver weapons on target, and detect possible threats. Common avionics include radar, sonar, communications, head-up-display, forward-looking infrared, navigation, and aircraft monitoring instrumentation. More advanced avionics enables aircraft to operate much more effectively by detecting and killing threats earlier and quicker.

Aerial countermeasures are devices that thwart the targeting system of an incoming missile in order to defeat the attack. Missiles use either infrared sensors to lock onto the heat signature of an aircraft’s engines or radar to find their mark. Because they usually have a very narrow field of view, aircraft-deployed countermeasures like flares, which create false heat sources, and chaff, which creates false radar contacts, can defeat the missile’s ability to track its target.

Although missiles dominate post-WWII air combat, airborne cannon have not been rendered obsolete. Effective cannon give an aircraft a powerful ground-attack capability and can even be used as an emergency backup in air to air combat. Aircraft cannon are usually 20-30mm and employ a rotary cluster of barrels for maximum rate of fire.

Airborne gunnery is extremely challenging because of the aircraft’s speed and altitude: not only must a gunner lead his target, he must compensate for his height relative to it as well. The simplest way to mitigate these challenges is to fire hundreds of rounds in quick succession and to ‘walk’ fire onto the target. Multiple revolving barrel firearms are best suited to this task due to their ability to cope with the enormous heat of firing thousands of rounds per minute.

A rotary cannon, also known as a ‘Gatling-type cannon,’ employs a cluster of rotating barrels in order to sustain a rate of fire far greater than single-barreled cannons of similar caliber. The rotating barrel cluster enables barrels to be loaded, fired, and unloaded sequentially as the cluster rotates, and also allows some time for the barrels to cool down between shots. Rotary cannon are particularly useful on aircraft because their volume of fire compensates for the inherent inaccuracy of airborne gunnery.

Air-to-air missiles are fired from an aircraft for the purpose of destroying another aircraft. They are typically powered by a solid-fuel rocket motor, but liquid-fueled motors are sometimes used. Missile guidance takes the form of either radar or infrared targeting. Long range missiles generally use radar guidance, and dogfight missiles generally use infrared guidance. Air-to-air missiles use blast or fragmentation to kill their target, detonated by a proximity fuse. Some even use nuclear warheads.

Air-to-ground weapons are designed to attack ground targets from aircraft. Such weapons include air-to-surface missiles, unguided rockets, air-launched cruise missiles, and conventional bombs. Ordnance can be carried in a bomb bay or on hung from a hardpoint on the exterior of the aircraft.

Napalm is a thickening agent that is normally mixed with petroleum or other fuel to create an incendiary gel. It was originally developed in WWII, but improvements to the original mixture can make it burn longer and ignite at a higher temperature. When ignited, napalm burns at 800-1200°C (1500-2200°F) and smears when touched, making it an excellent anti-personnel weapon and defoliant. Napalm also has an extreme psychological impact on those attacked with it, and sometimes it is used for this effect alone.

Radar detects objects by bouncing electromagnetic waves off them and observing the signal. Therefore, an object which either reflects the waves in a direction away from the receiver or which does not reflect waves at all will be invisible to radar detection. The object of stealth technology is to achieve this effect. Aircraft shape plays a large role in radar cross-section, but the development of radar-absorbent materials is of equal importance to a true ‘stealth aircraft.’

Aircraft can be designed to minimize their radar cross section (RCS), but as an RCS dwindles in size, the aircraft’s design must become more extreme in its pursuit of stealth. The most basic way to reduce RCS is to keep an aircraft small: the bigger the plane, the bigger the RCS. More advanced stealth technology incorporates hard angular geometry to scatter radar signals, special radar-absorbent paint, and supersmooth surfaces.

Acoustic stealth involves the reduction of aircraft noise in order to avoid detection by enemy troops below. Although fixed wing aircraft can fly at subsonic speeds to avoid acoustic detection and supersonic aircraft are proof that acoustic stealth is not always important, helicopters and low flying ground attack craft stand to benefit enormously from the ability to operate quietly. Engine noise can be dampened, but quieting helicopter rotors requires advanced technology.

A fighter aircraft is designed to win air superiority over the battlefield. Fighters of the piston era relied on guns and cannon to shoot down other aircraft and were designed to prevail in swirling aerial dogfights. With the advent of radar-guided air-to-air missiles and jet propulsion, however, fighter speed and flight ceiling became more important than sheer maneuverability. Some fighters double as light attack aircraft and are known as fighter-bombers, but the fighter’s focus is on air-to-air combat.

A multirole fighter is a combat aircraft designed to perform many different combat missions previously relegated to special-purpose aircraft. In addition to its air-to-air combat role, a multirole fighter can also, for instance, also operate as a reconnaissance, ground attack, maritime interdiction, and air defense aircraft. The motivation for developing a multirole fighter is usually to reduce the number of different models of aircraft among allies, and to reduce supply and logistical costs.

WWII cemented the importance of close air support (CAS) in warfare and the need for specialized CAS aircraft. Although fighters can perform CAS missions, specialized CAS aircraft possess better handling characteristics at the low speeds and altitude that characterize CAS missions. CAS aircraft must also be able to carry plenty of ordnance, precisely target the enemy’s positions, possess the ability to loiter over the battlefield, and be able to stay aloft despite taking heavy damage.

Carrier-based fighters maintain air superiority around a carrier task force. They are equipped with advanced avionics, long and short range air-to-air missiles, and are capable of very high speeds. Carrier operations require carrier-based fighters to be built very robustly in order to withstand short takeoffs and landings and to incorporate space-saving features like folding wings.

Multirole carrier aircraft are able to perform many missions previously relegated to specialized aircraft, including air-superiority, surface and subsurface attack, and aerial reconnaissance. Like all carrier-based aircraft, multirole aircraft must incorporate carrier-specific features like folding wings and arrestor hooks.

Attack aircraft give a carrier task force its offensive punch. Their mission is to penetrate the enemy’s defensive umbrella and engage surface vessels with air-to-surface missiles. Attack aircraft are specially designed to perform this hazardous mission and are optimized for low-altitude flight, long range, and high durability. Advanced attack aircraft benefit from high speed and are better able to avoid interception on their attack run.

Maritime bombers patrol over water to find and kill enemy naval forces, especially submarines. They possess advanced avionics and long endurance. Maritime bombers are not carrier based craft: instead, they operate from costal airfields and rely on their long range to reach their patrol zones. As a result, maritime bombers can carry much more sensory equipment and ordinance than smaller carrier based aircraft.

Anti-submarine bombers are aircraft designed specifically to conduct anti-submarine warfare (ASW). Their sensors include sonar buoys, surface search radar capable of detecting periscopes, magnetic anomaly detection gear, and advanced networking in order to take advantage of permanent sea floor and buoy sensors. Anti-submarine bombers carry torpedoes and anti-submarine missiles to engage any subs that they detect.

Strike bombers (also known as attack bombers) are aircraft designed to attack ground targets with greater precision than strategic bombers. They differ from close air support (CAS) aircraft in the scope of their intended mission: strike bombers generally perform more interdiction and long range attack missions than CAS aircraft, but the roles of the two types of aircraft overlap significantly. Strike bombers also carry a larger payload than CAS aircraft, enabling them to effectively target enemy installations.

Strategic bombers destroy the economic and industrial capability of an enemy state to make war by systematically bombing cities, factories, and infrastructure. The advent of nuclear weapons gives strategic bombers unprecedented destructive potential. Furthermore, the strategic bomber’s long range and loiter time gives it a strategic second strike capability in a mutually-assured destruction scenario. Modern strategic bombers rely on speed and stealth to perform their mission.

Military transport aircraft are used to deliver troops, weapons, fuel, vehicles, and other cargo to areas of military operations. Military transports are very long range and extremely reliable, but require long runways to take off and land. Advanced transports can land on shorter runways and refuel in midair, enhancing their usefulness. Transport aircraft are able to airlift supplies wherever they are needed and are an enormous asset to any military.

Reconnaissance aircraft are designed to fly over a nation’s territory in order to gather imagery, signals, and measurement and signature intelligence. To avoid interception, reconnaissance aircraft are designed to either fly too fast and high for surface-to-air missiles to reach, or to hug the ground and infiltrate under the radar. Advances in stealth technology directly benefit the effectiveness of reconnaissance aircraft.

Airborne Early Warning and Control (AEW&C) aircraft employ advanced radar sensors to detect enemy aircraft, ships, and vehicles at long range and direct friendly air assets to strike these targets. AEW&C aircraft also conduct surveillance and can provide command and control for land operations. These aircraft are also deployed with carrier task forces to augment the carrier’s own sensors and command and control capabilities.

The helicopter’s utility as a gun platform is not obvious: it is slower than fixed wing aircraft and much more fragile. Therefore, helicopters were initially only armed with light weapons for self defense while inserting or extracting troops. However, the helicopter’s ability to loiter over a battlefield and to utilize fine contours in the terrain for cover proved their worth as gunships. With the addition of modular gun systems, existing utility helicopters can be modified to provide ad-hoc close air support.

Attack helicopters are designed to maximize the helicopter’s intrinsic abilities to exploit terrain for cover and to loiter closely over a battlefield in order to provide immediate close air support. These helicopters carry a myriad of weaponry to engage ground targets, including guided air-to-ground missiles, autocannon, rockets, and machine guns. Attack helicopters can also carry air-to-air missiles, but these are intended only for self-defense.

Helicopters are a natural fit for naval forces, fulfilling a wide variety of roles. Initially they were used to supplement fixed wing craft in reconnaissance operations and to rescue downed pilots. Improvements in helicopter power and endurance make them excellent anti-submarine craft. In this role, they are armed with torpedoes and fitted with sophisticated radar, dipping sonar, and magnetic anomaly detection equipment. Soviet helicopters have the added role of guiding long range anti-ship missiles to their targets.

Vertical takeoff and landing (VTOL) is the ability for a fixed wing aircraft to hover, take off, and vertically by directing its jet engine thrust downward using nozzles or aerodynamic surfaces. VTOL aircraft may also be capable of short takeoff and landing (STOL) which uses much less fuel than pure VTOL but allows the aircraft to take off and land using very truncated runways. VTOL aircraft are especially useful for navies that focus on deploying helicopter carriers over full-size carriers.

Signals intelligence is the process of gathering intelligence by intercepting signals either between people or by intercepting electronically-transmitted information. Signals intelligence is an extremely intensive process because valuable signals are often very difficult to intercept, and once obtained, are often encrypted or ambiguous. Signals intelligence is therefore a cross-disciplinary endeavor, incorporating electronic monitoring, information analysis, decryption, and old-fashioned detective work.

Encryption is a method for keeping communications secret. A message is encrypted by converting its contents into an unreadable ciphertext by means of an encryption algorithm. The ciphertext should be illegible to anyone who lacks the decryption key, which specifies how the ciphertext should be de#CODEd. Encryption therefore allows the secure broadcast of messages despite interception of them. More advanced encryption techniques are harder for third parties to crack and are consequently more secure.

Decryption encompasses the methods for ‘cracking’ intercepted messages that have been encrypted. Normally, only a party with the appropriate decryption key can read ciphertext, but it can also be deduced with mathematical pattern analysis of the message. The more advanced the encryption method, the harder it is to crack. However, advances in computer technology make pattern analysis much quicker and more efficient when used by skilled cryptographers.

Espionage (spying) is the process of obtaining secret information without the permission of the owner or holder of the information. Governments will go to great lengths to protect classified information, even as far as ‘disappearing’ individuals thought to be engaging in espionage against them. Therefore, espionage agencies focus heavily on recruiting effective agents, developing methods to ensure that their agents avoid discovery, and ensuring that they remain under the agency’s control.

Counterintelligence refers to the methods by which a country attempts to thwart foreign incursions into its own secret information. Counterintelligence encompasses screening and surveillance of persons with access to secret information and offensive counterespionage activities targeted at enemy agents. Generally, counterintelligence operations are focused on maintaining information security within a nation’s borders.

Human intelligence sources recruited from ‘inside’ a location or institution generally can neither practically receive nor benefit from espionage training – attempting to train them would likely attract suspicion. However, spies who must penetrate a location from the outside, usually a very risky proposition, may benefit greatly from expert instruction. Exactly what kind of training a spy receives depends heavily on the location of the target intelligence. More effective training regimes yield more effective spies.

The ability to know what the enemy is communicating remains the holy grail of intelligence gathering operations. The most direct way to achieve this is to literally listen – or look – in on his conversations. Surveillance equipment ranges in sophistication from an ear against a wall to high-tech devices capable of hearing a conversation at a distance. The rise of electronic communications adds another layer to surveillance activities, requiring new techniques and equipment.

An intelligence academy is a program in a nation’s intelligence service that prepares future intelligence personnel for intelligence gathering operations. Such an academy produces intelligence officers who are highly skilled in all aspects of intelligence gathering, from signals intelligence and analysis to spy training and recruitment.

Internal security agencies are established to ensure the security of secret information possessed by the state. These agencies actively work to seek out internal spies who attempt to gain access to secret information and determine the origins of any apprehended agents, their mission, and whether there are any additional spies operating inside the state’s borders. If unchecked, internal security agencies tend to discover intricate plots where none exist and accuse innocent citizens of crimes they did not commit.

A double agent is an employee of an intelligence organization whose mission is to spy on a target organization, but who in fact is working for that same target organization. Double agents are most useful in sewing disinformation or conducting counterespionage for their sponsor organization because they are usually highly trusted individuals in their home organization. The methods and techniques for ‘turning’ a captured agent into a double agent are more of an art than a science, requiring creativity and finesse.

A hidden camera is a still or video camera used to film individuals or locations without being detected. It is ‘hidden’ because it is either not visible to its subjects or because it has been disguised to look like another object. Cameras can be ‘hidden in plain sight’ such as in public squares and streets simply by disguising them as non-noteworthy features like birds’ nests, statuary, drainpipes, etc. Cameras hidden in more private areas, like offices and apartments, generally must be very small to avoid detection by their subjects.

Microtransmitters are tiny electronic devices able to pick up audio signals, particularly conversations, and transmit the signal to a recording device elsewhere. They are used for covert surveillance of individuals whenever the individuals’ knowledge that they are being recorded would compromise the quality of the gathered intelligence. Installing microtransmitters in a useful location is usually the most challenging aspect of their use.

A shell company, also known as a front company, is a company that is used as a vehicle for business transactions without holding any significant assets of its own. Although shell companies have a legitimate business purpose, they are easy to use for illegal – or clandestine – activities such as tax avoidance. In the espionage context, a shell company can provide a convenient excuse for the presence of intelligence personnel in a particular country.

A resident spy is an agent living in a targeted country. These spies range in profile from consular employees to citizens of the target nation. These types of spies drip information to their handlers over years or even decades, not in a sudden torrent. Therefore, because the amount of intelligence per agent is small, agencies must cultivate networks of such agents to provide an accurate intelligence picture. Building and maintaining these networks requires methodical planning and institutional competency.

Disinformation is intentionally false information spread deliberately for the purpose of deception. In espionage, disinformation operations target opposing intelligence gatherers – known or unknown – in order to mislead them. Disinformation is especially effective when it comes from a source that the opposing intelligence gatherers trust, such as from one of their own agents.

Interrogation is the process of extracting information from a captured individual by interviewing him or her. Interrogation may involve a range of techniques, from building a rapport with the subject to outright torture. The quality of the information obtained is heavily influenced by the skill of the interrogators in using interrogation their techniques.

A coup d'etat is the sudden overthrow of a government or state establishment, typically by a small group of highly-organized and coordinated individuals, and its replacement with another body, either civil or military. Engineering a coup d'etat requires organizing a core group of operatives capable of pulling off the operation and who will also agree to install a regime friendly to the sponsor intelligence agency. The consequence of a failed coup is not just national embarrassment for the sponsor – but also civil war.

A modern assassin is an individual who commits murder for political reasons or simply for money. Intelligence agencies may employ assassins to eliminate key political figures or individuals who they believe will compromise some part of an intelligence operation. Intelligence agencies who use assassins in this way must take great precautions to avoid being tied to the assassination: any country who publicly assassinates its opponents will become a pariah in the international community.

A thermonuclear weapon derives its high yield from its use of hydrogen fusion to power additional nuclear fission that would otherwise sputter out. The so-called ‘hydrogen bomb’ works in two stages: a normal implosion fission bomb is detonated as a trigger for the second stage fissile material, the detonation of which produces enough heat and pressure to trigger fusion. The released energy generates optimal conditions for additional fission to occur, thus producing a much more destructive blast.

Nuclear power is generated by using heat released by the nuclear fission of low-enriched uranium and plutonium to spin a steam turbine connected to a generator. Nuclear fission is an extremely efficient means of generating heat, making nuclear reactors very efficient sources of electricity. However, spent nuclear fuel is extremely radioactive and remains dangerous for hundreds of thousands of years after use. Nevertheless, nuclear power is used whenever efficiency trumps safety, such as in warships.

Enriched uranium is the fissile material that is critical to nuclear power generation and construction of nuclear weapons. Obtaining enriched uranium is difficult because the two types of uranium are chemically very similar to one another, making them difficult to separate. The two primary ways of separating out enriched uranium are through gaseous diffusion, which forces a gaseous uranium compound through a filter, and gas centrifuge, which uses strong centrifugal force from rapidly rotating cylinders.

A weapons delivery system is the means by which a weapon is brought in close enough proximity to its target to destroy it. Targets of nuclear weapons include cities and industrial or military installations, or specific military formations of troops or materiel. Thus, large warheads are required and their means of delivery must be up to the task. The most basic delivery system is by conventional bomber. However, advanced ballistic missiles can be used, including those launched from beneath the ocean’s surface.

Atomic theory has its origins in the ancient Greek ‘Atomism’ school of philosophy. Originally, atoms were conceived as the smallest possible unit of matter, indivisible and singular. However, by the early 20th century science had discovered through experimentation that atoms were in fact composed of smaller, subatomic particles that could be split apart and accrete together. The scientific quest to understand and control the physics of these subatomic particles is the foundation for modern atomic theory.

Nuclear strategy is a nation’s doctrine for how to best use its nuclear weapons, what kinds of weapons to develop and in what quantities, and how to best produce nuclear weapons for its needs. Nuclear strategy can focus either on the tactical use of nuclear weapons or on their strategic use for deterring aggression. Nuclear weapons can even be used as diplomatic bargaining chips. Nuclear strategy is distinguishable from military strategy because of the unprecedented destructive power of nuclear weapons.

Delivery of a nuclear bomb by conventional bomber is easier said than done. A nuclear bomb must be able to withstand flight vibrations, and both remain operational when delivered on target and not detonate prematurely. It must also be light enough to stay within bomber payload limits. Some modes of delivery include parachute-retarded delivery, which gives more time for the bomber to escape the blast, and toss bombing, where the aircraft pulls up as the bomb is released in order to extend its range.

Intercontinental Ballistic Missiles (ICBMs) are nuclear-tipped missiles with ranges long enough to strike targets thousands of miles/kilometers away. Initially, ICBMs were based on a nation’s home soil because this location was seen as most secure. Early ICBMs could only target cities due to their inaccuracy and also took a long time to set up before launch. With advances in rocket propulsion, guidance, and weapons systems like MIRVs, ICBMs became smaller, more accurate, and faster to set up.

A submarine-launched ballistic missile (SLBM) is a nuclear tipped missile capable of being launched from a submarine while submerged. SLBMs carry enormous strategic significance in the Cold War nuclear standoff. No longer can a nation hope to knock out its adversary’s second-strike capability with a pre-emptive attack: SLBMs will always be capable of mounting an apocalyptic retaliatory strike even when all land-based systems are destroyed.

It became evident in WWII that ballistic missiles are only susceptible to intercept by other missiles. However, anti-ballistic missile (ABM) technology is inherently complex and heavily reliant on integrated systems of radar tracking and targeting. Adding to the problem of ABM tech is sheer economics: it is very easy to simply produce ICBMs in quantities that will overwhelm any ABM system. This problem becomes especially acute with the advent of multiple independently targetable reentry vehicle technology.

‘I begin to believe in only one civilizing influence: the discovery one of these days of a destructive agent so terrible that War shall mean annihilation and men's fears will force them to keep the peace.’ –Wilkie Collins, 1870. Mutually-Assured Destruction (MAD) deters nuclear war by ensuring that each nuclear combatant understands that any attack by it on the other will be met with an immediate escalation of nuclear force so comprehensive that the aggressor will be annihilated, and cease to exist as a functioning state.

Second strike capability refers to the ability of a nation to retaliate with nuclear weapons even after an aggressor has conducted a nuclear attack against it. This ability underlies the doctrine of mutually-assured destruction: without it, a nuclear combatant would simply launch a massive nuclear strike to knock out the enemy’s nuclear forces. The most effective means of assuring a second strike capability is with the use of ballistic missile submarines, but land-based nuclear silos or conventional bombers also work.

A departure from the established mutually-assured destruction status-quo, countervailing strategy is predicated on the Soviet leadership’s inherent interest in self-preservation. The strategy calls for the immediate killing of the Soviet leadership and military in the event of nuclear war instead of targeting Soviet population centers. The rationale was that such a nuclear response would decapitate the USSR and force it to surrender, allowing more moderation than was possible under the apocalyptic MAD scenario.

The specter of ICBM-delivered nuclear annihilation dominated the Cold War era in part because offensive missile technology remained so superior to defensive technology. The Strategic Defense Initiative (SDI) aims to tip the balance back in the defense’s favor. SDI employs an integrated system of ground assets and space-based laser weapons and monitoring stations to shoot down incoming ICBMs. If operational, SDI would give a nation first-strike capability, perhaps also tipping the balance of the MAD status-quo.

Attempts to contain the spread (proliferation) of nuclear weapons began in WWII with the Allied bombing of German heavy water plants. However, non-wartime efforts at nuclear nonproliferation take the form of either espionage or international treaty. Additionally, the International Atomic Energy Agency was established in 1957 to promote the peaceful use of nuclear power. Historically, the UN’s Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty was signed in 1978 to halt nuclear weapons production and reduce their numbers.

Using German V-2 rocket technology and derivative technology, the United States and Soviet Union began launching objects into the upper reaches of the earth’s atmosphere for scientific purposes. These research missions measured cosmic radiation, contained fruit flies for scientific study, and carried radio transmitters. All such flights were suborbital and only allowed a very brief time in space and were therefore of limited usefulness.

A launch vehicle is a rocket capable of carrying a payload from earth into space. The first purpose-built launch vehicles were developed by the United States and Soviet Union based on German rocket technology inherited after WWII. Although they were originally designed to deliver nuclear Armageddon, ICBMs historically provided an excellent foundation for a nation’s space program. However, functional launch vehicles are far harder to delpoy than ballistic missiles.

All functions necessary to the maintenance of human life must be artificially supplied in space. This is a huge challenge for systems designers, particularly when the human body’s reaction to microgravity is not fully understood. The first step to designing effective life support systems is to determine exactly what a human needs while in space. This involves exhaustive physiological testing of human and animal subjects, as well as the development of technology that can mimic conditions found in space.

A satellite is an object following an orbital trajectory around a gravitational body. Putting an object into orbit involves accelerating it to so great a speed that its ballistic trajectory no longer intersects with the earth’s surface – a satellite is a falling object that misses. The engineering required to achieve a stable orbit is immensely precise and complex. Devices must operate autonomously or at the most with radio inputs, but must be tough enough to withstand launch.

The electrical requirements of spacecraft present a steep challenge to their designers. High-yield solutions like Apollo’s fuel cells or miniature nuclear reactors are too heavy for most missions. The only abundant source of energy in space is the sun’s solar radiation, but only if materials can be developed capable of converting light into electricity. More advanced solar cells can more efficiently convert solar energy to electrical power, allowing for more complex spacecraft.

Ground-based astronomy is limited by the earth’s atmosphere that diffuses light in all directions – making the sky blue. Therefore, a telescope which orbits above most of the earth’s atmosphere is a far superior astronomical instrument. Engineering an orbital observatory involves ensuring that the precise optics survive launch, the device can accurately orient itself to look at objects in the sky, and that the images can return to earth for study.

Development of reconnaissance (spy) satellite technology has been pursued from the outset of spaceflight. The advantage of an orbiting telescope pointed at the ground is obvious to any commander. Spy satellites fly above the reach of surface-to-air missiles and are excellent at gathering strategic intelligence about an enemy’s military materiel build-up, thus enabling smart strategic decision making. Early spy satellites parachuted their film back to earth for retrieval but later models used encrypted radio transmissions.

Experimentation with pressurized aircraft cockpits began in the 1920s and accelerated due to the demands of WWII bomber crews who needed to move around the aircraft unencumbered by oxygen masks. By the 1940s, pressurized passenger planes were common. Spacecrafts’ cabins must be pressurized because the technology required to create a spacesuit is vastly more complex than the demands of building a pressurized spacecraft, and the system must function reliably and safely at all times.

A shirt-sleeve environment is an aeronautical term that describes the interior of an aircraft in which no special clothing need be worn. High-altitude flight necessitated very warm clothing and even oxygen masks, but the ability to pressurize aircraft cabins enabled crews to operate in only 'shirt sleeves.' A spacecraft with such an environment benefits from a crew whose mobility and dexterity is unimpaired, but the craft’s life support systems must be very efficient to maintain such agreeable environmental conditions.

An enormous amount of energy and planning is needed to put a man in space and return him safely to earth. Launch sites must be surveyed and constructed, hangars built to house the rockets, central mission control conceptualized and implemented, personnel trained to manage operations, and the spacecraft itself designed and built. A successful manned space mission begins with careful planning.

The mechanics of spaceflight alone are astounding, so for a human to successfully complete an orbit around the earth is a monumental feat worthy of national celebration. Steps toward this goal had to start small, progressing from unoccupied suborbital probes to artificial satellites, then to satellites occupied by human stand-ins like dogs or monkeys. Launching a man into space is truly pioneering, therefore all systems and procedures must be comprehensively vetted before launch day.

At a minimum, a spacesuit must provide a pressurized environment, temperature regulation, breathable oxygen, a communications system, and waste-collection capability. An EVA spacesuit must additionally provide, at a minimum, protection against radiation & micrometeoroids and a tether to the spacecraft. Spacesuit construction follows either a soft or hard-shell philosophy, with the latter giving more protection at the expense of less dexterity. Modern suits are of composite soft-hard design.

Circumlunar trajectory is a type of return trajectory that takes a spacecraft from Earth, around the far side of the Moon, and back to Earth. It uses the Moon’s gravity to bend the spacecraft’s trajectory around the Moon and point it back toward the Earth. Because it uses no propulsion, this type of return trajectory is referred to as a “free return” trajectory. Historically, the Soviet Union’s Luna 3 was the first spacecraft to employ a circumlunar trajectory.

The Moon orbits approximately 384,000 km from the earth: by comparison, manned spacecraft rarely stray past 2,000 km because of fuel requirements. Needless to say, a ‘moonshot’ is an epic engineering feat. Everything about an attempt to land on the moon is unprecedented. The largest and most powerful rocket in history must be built and function flawlessly, a long-endurance spacecraft capable of reaching the Moon must be constructed, and its crew must expertly pilot it onto the lunar surface.

Space is an environment so alien from earth that all assumptions must be cast aside when attempting to understand and operate in it. For instance, because normal methods of locomotion are ineffective in an environment of frictionless microgravity, each spacecraft maneuver must be exhaustively planned and expertly executed to avoid disaster. This technology covers the planning of highly complex space operations like rendezvous, mid-course maneuvers, docking, and extravehicular activity (spacewalks).

Microgravity conditions in low earth orbit present unique conditions for conducting scientific experiments, and the benefits of maintaining a long-term research craft in space do not stop there. Also of scientific interest is the astronomical view unhindered by earth’s atmosphere and the effect on human physiology of prolonged stays in space. Orbiting research stations may be designed to be expendable or to remain in orbit long-term, accepting later expansions and upgrades.

Permanent missions in space, or space station operations, impose unique demands compared to single flight operations. Furthermore, they are also vastly more complex because of their long-term nature. Logistical planning is paramount: the station’s crew must be continuously cycled in and out, the station resupplied, its orbit maintained, etc. As a result, planning permanent missions to space requires extensive and continuing coordination across all branches of a space program.

Living conditions are not given very high priority in short-duration spacecraft because the crew does not need to live in the craft for more than a week, typically. However, long-term residence in space requires that spacecraft designs emphasize crew comfort or risk psychological and physical fatigue. Spacious cabins, private sleeping spaces, varied and tasty food (preferably familiar earth dishes), exercise facilities, and social areas all must be engineered into the design of the spacecraft for long-term habitation.

Modular design is critical to the development of large spacecraft because the energy required to launch an object into space increases exponentially with the weight of the object. Modular spacecraft design enables the piecemeal launch of sections of the craft into orbit, to be assembled in space. These modules must be engineered for structural compatibility and the systems for integrating new modules must also function flawlessly.

Long term missions in space impose specific engineering and logistical challenges that are radically different than one-shot launch and return missions. Not only must an orbiting space station be designed to endure in the harsh environment of space, but the challenges of resupplying it, adjusting its orbit, and providing for its crew’s needs must also be met. Maintenance of a permanent space station is a huge test of the institutional competency of a nation’s space program.

The first consumer electronics were home radio sets, but the home electronic industry historically took off in the post-WWII United States. Intended to make life easier and richer for the average consumer, consumer electronics incorporate advances in cheap plastics and widespread electrification to make vacuum cleaners, televisions, electric washing machines, refrigerators, and so much more available at affordable prices. Consumers are urged to hurry and get theirs while supplies last.

Modern science refers to the post-Scientific Revolution establishment of a professional class of scientists who employ the scientific method to create theories based on experimentation with reproducible and objectively observable phenomena. The methods of modern science provide the foundation that all subsequent scientific discoveries are based. Without it, a state will never truly innovate in science or technology.

Mass production was first developed in the nineteenth century but became steadily more efficient through the twentieth, benefitting from factory electrification. Mass production enables the manufacture of huge quantities of standardized goods whose price decreases in proportion to the quantity produced. Because of this, mass production is very useful for producing consumer goods at affordable prices.

Home appliances carry the promise of a life of leisure to any who can afford their moderate price tag. Historically, the home appliance market exploded in the 1950s United States and spread to the rest of the world shortly thereafter. A nation’s excess post-WWII light industrial capacity could easily be retooled to produce toasters, blenders, sleek kitchen ranges, washing machines, and so much more for the middle-class consumer.

Plastics are moldable organic or synthetic polymers whose versatility ensures their integral role in modern light industry. Before the advent of plastics, the next best material for use in consumer goods was wood or thin stamped metal. Whereas the first can splinter and deteriorate, and the latter becomes dented and rusty, plastics remain true to their shape and do not discolor over time. There are many varieties of plastics, including Parkesine, Bakelite, and polyurethane.

‘Economy of scale’ refers to the decrease in the cost per unit that occurs when volume of production is expanded. As numbers of units produced increases, the individual cost of producing each unit decreases. Often, the expansion of production is accompanied by efficiency increases, e.g. when a company centralizes its factories into a single location. Cost savings from economies of scale drop off after a certain point depending on market conditions and industrial efficiency.

Mechanical parts, better known as machine tools, include dies and molds designed to produce the exact same part every time. These devices drive the industrial machines that shape raw materials into valuable goods, and therefore are always in high demand wherever industrial manufacture occurs. Machine parts must be of very high quality to be useful in industry.

Heavy mechanical engineering deals with designing, building, and troubleshooting machines used in heavy industry. Advances in heavy mechanical engineering allow heavy industrial processes like steel production, shipbuilding, etc, to be performed more efficiently, leading to higher rates of production and less waste.

Robots (autonomous machines) have many applications in heavy industry where tasks must be performed in conditions hazardous to human life. Furthermore, industrial robots can perform many jobs with far more precision and speed than any human worker. Examples include welding vehicles together and installing numerous parts in hard-to-reach places. Advanced robots are even able to detect flaws as they work, improving quality control.

Attempts to mechanize agriculture began in the nineteenth century, but the process came into its own in the twentieth century with the rise of large commercial farms. Mechanized agriculture uses tractors, combines, and other machines to efficiently harvest and process food.

Fertilizer, originally consisting of animal waste, is now largely commercially produced. The first synthetic fertilizers were produced in the 1920s and have been a key part of agriculture ever since. Not only are synthetic fertilizers easier to produce in great quantities, they are also engineered for fertilization efficiency. Crop yields with synthetic fertilizers are consequently much higher than with organic fertilizers.

Construction engineering deals with the design and construction of infrastructure, including highways, bridges, high rise apartment buildings, airports, ports, etc. Sound construction engineering practices ensure the long life and usefulness of these structures.

Modern physics arose with the development of quantum mechanics and Einsteinian relativity. Command of the former is essential for nations that wish to harness the atom’s potential for energy and weaponry.

Electronics is a catch-all term used for any equipment that relies heavily upon electricity, including everything from microprocessor computers to traffic signals. Advances in electronics directly benefit military technology by improving processing power and weapon capability.

Biology, the study of living organisms, has existed since ancient times, but modern biology began with the Enlightenment of the 18th century. In the second half of the 20th century, the biggest advances in Biology related to the discovery of DNA and genetic engineering. Genetic engineering in particular finds a myriad of cross-disciplinary applications.

The practical application of the science of biology, modern medicine arose at the end of the 18th century with Edward Jenner’s discovery of the smallpox vaccine. Since that time, it has cured the sick, healed the injured, and bettered the world to an unprecedented degree. Advances in medicine are directly applicable to the battlefield: wounds that would have been fatal in the past can be successfully treated by doctors behind the lines, and prosthetics can restore mobility to those who have lost limbs.

Political economy, originally the formal title for what is now known as economics, means in a modern sense the application of models for the behavior of economic agents in an economy. Some such models include Marxism, public choice, game theory, or even the popularization of economics by modern policy makers. As a whole, political economy attempts to explain how to achieve positive economic growth in a society.

Psychology, as a scientific profession, dates to the nineteenth century, although the modern techniques of psychoanalysis began with Sigmund Freud and Karl Jung. Modern psychology attempts to understand mental functions and behaviors of individuals. Some areas of interest to psychology are cognition, motivation, perception, and behavior.

Sociology, the study of human society and its institutions, began as an academic discipline with Emile Durkheim in the early 20th century, although figures from Spencer to Marx have made contributions. Sociology attempts to understand the origins, development, organization and institutions of human society. Insights gleaned with sociological research can be applied to programs for social welfare and policy.

Chemistry is the study of the interaction of elements and various processes relating to the elements. Modern chemistry has helped produce synthetic substitutes for previously rare goods, like diamonds, rubber, and oil. In doing so, it has revolutionized the way of life of people around the world who benefit every day from materials and processes made possible by modern chemistry.

‘Mathematics takes us still further from what is human, into the region of absolute necessity, to which not only the actual world, but every possible world, must conform.’ –Bertrand Russell. At its most basic level, mathematics is simply the ability to count, but by the late twentieth century, mathematics had led to inventions like computers and the necessary theory for every significant scientific advance to that point. Mathematics is the cognitive toolset for modeling how the universe functions.

Software is the abstraction of instructions for the operation of a computer: early digital computers were hardwired to only perform a certain function, but the development of software (in the form of punch cards) enabled the machines to be reprogrammed without changing the internal circuitry. Software engineering therefore refers to the systematic development and implementation of software to better operate computing machines, making them more efficient and powerful.

Mining is the process of extracting valuable minerals from the ground, particularly metals such as gold, silver, iron, and copper. Industry also requires large quantities of other minerals and metals such as coal and rare earth minerals. Mining and its related activities, like smelting, generally have a deleterious effect on the surrounding natural environment.

Oil drilling, both offshore and in land-based oil fields, is a critical part of modern economics. No modern economy can presently function without oil. However the logistics of obtaining oil drive up the cost of production and determine which oil fields will be exploited. When an oil well can no longer profitably produce oil, it is abandoned in favor of exploration elsewhere, even if extractable oil remains in the well. Consequently, extraction technology determines which oil fields are exploitable and which are not.

Refining is the process by which crude oil is converted into usable fuel, such as gasoline and kerosene. Crude oil is useless when it is first drilled from a well: it must be refined into petroleum products in order to become marketable. However, refining is a very intensive process that requires sprawling plants latticed with pipes and storage tanks. Moreover, the chemical process of refining oil releases many gasses into the atmosphere and emits liquid waste, polluting the environment with petrochemicals.

Electricity, in either AC or DC varieties, is produced by power plants and converted into a usable form for residential, industrial, and commercial uses. It is the mark of an advanced nation that all its citizens have access to electricity: the infrastructure necessary to achieve universal electrification is itself a noteworthy achievement.

Electric power conversion is the implementation of electrical equipment to convert electricity from AC to DC, or simply to adjust the voltage or current to a usable level at another location. Transformers, which convert main line electricity into lower voltages for individual consumption, are an important example of this technology. The more efficient the conversion rate, the less power must be generated at power plants to satiate consumer demand.

Recycling, or the methods and infrastructure for converting expended materials into another form for reuse, was largely a response to environmentalist movements throughout the second half of the twentieth century. By converting spent materials for reuse in other applications, recycling reduces not only landfill waste, but eases the need for extraction and processing of natural resources.

Computers are a product of World War II, particularly of cryptography. The first computers occupied entire buildings and could only accomplish relatively simple tasks, but as electronics technology progressed, computers become smaller and more efficient, able to complete millions – or even billions – of computations per second. A desktop computer with processing power greater than that of one hundred WWII decryption machines might be just around the corner.

Built using superconducting transistors, the integrated circuit made the computer revolution possible: it is the reason why computers are now the size of your fingernail instead of the size of the size of your house. An integrated circuit – also known as a microchip – is nothing more than a set of electrical circuits located in a single device. Integrated circuits have applications in high-tech militaries, such as in guided missiles and decryption technology.
